Alan Turing was a brilliant mathematician and computer scientist, a gifted code breaker and the father of modern computing. On June 7th 1954 he killed himself, eating an apple laced with cyanide. In 1952 he had been prosecuted and convicted for homosexuality and accepted chemical castration as an alternative to a custodial prison sentence. Homosexuality was finally decriminalised in England and Wales in 1967. On January 31st 2017 The Sexual Offences Pardons Bill 2016-17, a law created in his memory, granted posthumous pardons to around 46,000 people who were prosecuted for their homosexuality prior to 1967. Photo taken in Sachville Park, Manchester. Credit: Getty Images/Christopher Furlong

Polish astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus—founder of Copernican heliocentrism—died on May 24th, 1543. Earlier that year he published "De Revolutionibus Orbium Coelestium" ("On the Revolutions of the Heavenly Spheres"), which rejected the commonly held belief that the Earth was the centre of the Universe. His ideas were seminal for Renaissance astronomy and the Scientific Revolution

An aerial view of the Cotopaxi volcano as it spews ash, taken on August 18th 2015. Officials estimate nearly 325,000 people could be affected by an eruption of Cotopaxi, the volcano looming beyond the Ecuadorian capital of Quito. status_message: Margaret has terminal ovarian cancer. After five types of chemotherapy she wants to be able to decide the time and manner of her death. To find out more about doctor-assisted dying visit http://econ.st/1SPEKYj
link_name: Margaret's story: Why I support assisted dying

status_message: Not so long ago, countries mostly ignored their diasporas. But, rather like alumni relations offices, diaspora ministries and departments are now popping up around the world. When Ireland was struggling in 2009, it convened an expat conference aimed at convincing the well-to-do Irish diaspora to help the country get back on its feet http://econ.st/1J9Jpj9
link_name: What countries want from their diasporas

status_message: Sixty-five years ago the average grade at Harvard was around a C. Today it's about an A. The trend is evident across America's Ivy League. So are these prestigious universities embracing fewer rich dunderheads than they used to or have standards dropped? http://econ.st/1J9pEs5

At the site of natural disasters, when large areas are inaccessible, emergency teams can struggle to spot people in need of rescue. Drones can reveal them. Watch the full film on Facebook http://econ.st/1BE0fXk
link_name: The drone pilots who are saving lives

status_message: We invite you to imagine a world in which countries could move as easily as people. View our suggestions for a rearranged Europe in this videographic.

No country in the world imprisons as many people as America does, or for so long. Across the array of state and federal prisons, local jails and immigration detention centres, some 2.3m people are locked up at any one time. Unstoppable though the system's growth has seemed at times, in the past five years it has reached a plateau http://econ.st/1LoofAm

Carolyn Drake, a photographer, tells The Economist about life on the edge of the desert for the Uighur people of Xinjiang and their uneasy relationship with the Han Chinese, in light of continuing unrest in Urumqi Read our related article via: http://econ.st/1e46CZp

Bobby Jindal, the governor of Louisiana, sits down with The Economist to discuss standing up to Russia, calling radical Islam the enemy and fixing America's broken immigration system http://econ.st/1LoBpxf #econarchive
Audio: How mobile phone data can help aid workers during humanitarian crises and start-ups which tweak your phone's connectivity take on the big mobile network companies http://econ.st/1JjcD24

Multilateral trade deals mean common standards and lower barriers for all. The Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership is an ambitious planned trade deal between America and the EU. The potential benefits are hard to estimate, but opposition is strong. Even some economists argue that the boost to growth from the new deals will be small. Today's #Dailychart shows the largest global exporters http://econ.st/1JiZi9Q

Amid the many promises of Britain's first new majority government in a decade—including 200,000 new houses, 500 new schools, a new Jerusalem, maybe—hopeful Conservatives should heed the cautionary words of David Cameron. "Announcing something doesn't mean it will happen." http://econ.st/1J2O4mR

An economic history of the world in 1 minute, 5 seconds. 
China's economy now ranks as the world's biggest in purchasing-power-parity terms. But it is merely regaining a title that it has held for much of recorded history, as our video shows. The brief interlude in which America overshadowed it is now over.
link_name: An economic history of the world in 1 minute, 5 seconds

status_message: Japan's national debt: There's nothing like optimism—except where it's unrealistic http://econ.st/1KaskZy

Audio: As the deadline for repayment looms, Greece finally offers a concrete set of reforms, Russian assets are seized abroad and a look at China's booming and busting stock markets http://econ.st/1e1PD9W

Since the financial crisis all manner of sovereign debtors have sought relief. Ukraine wants concessions from bondholders; Greece, which has already obtained that, wants forgiveness from other governments too. But new research suggests the relationship between debt relief and economic growth is not as straightforward as campaigners claimed http://econ.st/1SFP7xC

Archive: Inequality sits at the top of the political agenda in many countries around the world. Economists say that some inequality is needed to propel growth. Without the carrot of large financial rewards, risky entrepreneurship and innovation would grind to a halt. Over the past generation or two inequality has risen most in places where progressive policies, such as high top tax-rates, have been weakened http://econ.st/1JeDKeD
link_name: Thomas Piketty on the history of money

Despite the mass shootings, meaningful gun control is now politically impossible in America http://econ.st/1K6MmUJ

Britain's economy is back on track, growing faster last year than any other in the G7 group of rich countries. But for David Cameron, the welcome boomlet presents an inconvenience. Five years ago, when the economy was in the doldrums, the prime minister made a foolish vow drastically to reduce immigration. The promise always looked unrealistic. Now, as the economy fires up and firms recruit, it threatens to become crippling http://econ.st/1BvrpzG
Thanks to ultra-long sentences, America's 2.3m prisoners are getting older. Under the "Gold coats" programme in California, younger inmates look after elderly ones http://econ.st/1LnzYwT

Meet the people pioneering new careers as drone pilots, from the South African savannah to the building sites of California. This is the first film in our new "Future Works" series, which looks at the jobs of tomorrow being done today. To watch more visit Economist.com/films

When scripts were bad, as they often were, he refused to speak them. Some of his best performances were silent, save for the odd gasp and groan: both as the Mummy in 1959, and as the Creature in "The Curse of Frankenstein" (1957), he contrived to bring pathos, stateliness and complexity to characters almost entirely swathed in bandages, patched with stitches or smothered in fake gangrene. Christopher Lee, portrayer of villains, died on June 7th, aged 93 http://econ.st/1Frt30f

Sokoto epitomises the miserable destitution across Nigeria's northern states. Without serious reform, the region could become a breeding ground for further insecurity http://econ.st/1FpiuuD

A student flying to Ibiza for his holiday found his girlfriend's stepfather had booked him on a flight under the name Adam West, rather than his actual name, Adam Armstrong. Ryanair told him it would cost £220 ($337) to change the name on the booking. Splendidly, the 19-year-old avoided the cost by changing his surname by deed poll. The scheme cost him less than half the Ryanair charge http://econ.st/1Fr7LzY

status_message: Occasionally, handsome men choose plain women, and vice versa. Why this should be vexes psychologists and biologists alike. A study by Lucy Hunt of the University of Texas at Austin, and her colleagues, soon to be published in Psychological Science, suggests an answer. It depends on whether the couples in questions were friends before they were lovers http://econ.st/1FpnD6a

In a digital rerun of Britain's trial of the publishers of "Lady Chatterley's Lover" in 1960, Megumi Igarashi, a Japanese artist is currently fighting obscenity charges for her namecards. Plenty of people in Japan, however, seem to be missing the joke http://econ.st/1LcKeuK

Twitter's share price was up nearly 2% on news that its chief executive, Dick Costolo, will step down on July 1st. The microblogging site's co-founder and chairman, Jack Dorsey, will replace him temporarily. Although the number of monthly active users topped 300m in the first quarter, growth has been slowing; revenue of $436m, though up 74% year-on-year, was less than expected http://econ.st/1FhcSCO

On June 4th Saudi Arabia and Israel admitted at a conference in America that they have held a series of meetings. Their improving ties are a manifestation of shared strategic interests, says Ilan Mizrahi, a former head of Israel's National Security Council. "Like us, the Saudis are worried about Iran, IS and the fear that America is no longer so committed." http://econ.st/1cRyOO4

In most places a model's good looks would make him or her a catch. Not in Saudi Arabia. Since a ruling this month that has effectively banned fashion shows, Saudi models have been speaking of their hardships. "My fiancé left me the moment he heard I was a model," says a woman quoted in local media. But officials are fighting a losing battle: Saudis will continue to strut their stuff on or off the catwalk http://econ.st/1Ia5tqV

Campus activists have stretched the meaning of safety from an important but second-order concern—shielding students from serious harm—to a defining ambition for any well-run academy. Students have declared and administrators accepted that teachers or visiting speakers should aim for a psychologically safe learning environment. Student "safety" has become a real threat to free speech on campus http://econ.st/1TehiVC

The derivation of "barbecue" from the Spanish for "beard" and "tail" is a popular etymology but false. Barbacoa was an Arawak Indian word for an interlaced frame of wood supported on posts and used either to sleep on or to preserve meat and fish by drying. Eventually in Spanish it described meat roasted over such a frame and in time entered English as "barbecue": Letters to the Editor http://econ.st/1GrHYN7
Decades after the worst industrial accident in India's history, many residents of Bhopal feel they were abandoned to suffer its toxic effects http://econ.st/1QoH4HY #econarchive

More big American firms are run by men called John than by women. But today some management scholars argue that women excel in the leadership qualities most valued in modern firms. Some ask whether the financial crisis would have been as bad had Lehman Brothers been Lehman Sisters, given research suggesting a link between testosterone levels and risk-taking http://econ.st/1KPcTpD

After a spate of murderous attacks in Durban and Johannesburg on migrant workers from neighbouring countries, South Africa badly needs to improve its image on the continent. But rhetoric and reality are a long way apart. One ongoing mission is undiplomatically called Operation Fiela, a word meaning "sweep away dirt" or "clean up" http://econ.st/1IDgeYq
Audio: This week our correspondents discuss the sweeping changes at Deutsche Bank and HSBC and Iceland's capital controls http://econ.st/1IDQZFm

These are high times for discerning drug users. For years they made do with poor quality drugs. But now the purity of cocaine, ecstasy and heroin is rising across Britain. Over the past five years the average purity of cocaine has gone up from 18% to 51%. In parts of the country police have seen cocaine that is 90% pure of late. Why? http://econ.st/1S2gn9m

One in five labour-market entrants in Bulgaria and Romania is a Roma, says the World Bank; one in six in Hungary and Slovakia. Schools in Roma neighbourhoods, where 30-60% of them live, are dismal. Segregation is common. Life is not improving for one of Europe's biggest and most ostracised minorities http://econ.st/1FAu6MX

Women in Saudi Arabia have to adhere to restrictive social codes based on an extreme interpretation of Islam. But as calls for reform increase, their lot is starting to change http://econ.st/1HmDRTm #econarchive
Audio: "War Art with Eddie Redmayne" examines the artists of the first world war including the creators of false trees, anti-torpedo dazzle paint and portraits of the wounded http://econ.st/1Gmqqlz

With its red phone boxes, statue of Winston Churchill and Anglicized church, Thames Town looks just like an English city, but it was built to house suburban residents of Shanghai #econarchive http://econ.st/1Gm1xGF

For centuries, boys were top of the class. But these days, that's no longer the case.
Why are girls now doing better at school than boys? When it comes to the students who really struggle, the difference is stark: boys are 50% more likely than girls to fall short of basic standards in all three areas of reading, mathematics and science. We look at why boys are doing badly—and how to fix it http://econ.st/1Qichwj
link_name: Why girls do better at school than boys

status_message: Sixty-five years ago the average grade at Harvard was around a C. Today it's about an A. The trend is evident across America's Ivy League. So are these prestigious universities embracing fewer rich dunderheads than they used to or have standards dropped? And which students now get the easiest ride? http://econ.st/1dRTpDq

The Shangri-La Dialogue, an annual powwow in Singapore for Asia-Pacific defence chiefs, has begun to follow a pattern: America and its friends in Asia line up to criticise China for its alleged transgressions in the seas around its coast; China issues fierce, mendacious and unconvincing rebuttals; everybody goes home http://econ.st/1H6d1Pk

As Turkey votes in parliamentary elections, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is hoping his party will win enough votes to force through constitutional change to give him increased powers http://econ.st/1MtSILX

Archive: A recent study by the OECD examined how 15-year-old boys and girls performed at reading, mathematics and science. Boys still score somewhat better at maths, and in science the genders are roughly equal. But when it comes to the students who really struggle, the difference is stark: boys are 50% more likely than girls to fall short of basic standards in all three areas http://econ.st/1dSxgVu

When men with jobs are in short supply, as they are in poor neighbourhoods throughout the rich world, any presentable male can get sex, but few women will trust him to stick around or behave decently. In 1960, there were 139 men aged 25-34 with jobs for every 100 women, with or without jobs. By 2012 there were only 91 employed men for every 100 women in this group. Thanks to mass incarceration, there are only 50 black men with jobs for every 100 black women in some American inner cities. In theory black women could "marry out", but few do: in 2010 only 9% of black female newly-weds married men of another race. On the plight of men and what it means for the future of marriage http://econ.st/1KeFN1c

On May 19th official statisticians announced that Britain entered deflation in April, with consumer prices standing 0.1% lower than a year earlier. It is first time since 1960 that annual inflation has been negative. If Britons start accepting lower pay rises on account of stagnant prices, deflation could persist http://econ.st/1cZd6YW

FIFA, football's world governing body, is having a rough few days. FIFA is worried that its sponsors are displeased by the latest bout of scandals. status_message: Archive: Since 1990, the number of people defined as the world's poorest group – living on less than $1.25 per day – has halved. But hunger levels have only gone down by a fifth. The prevailing wisdom is that to eliminate nutrition problems we had to produce more food and facilitate access to it. So now that fewer people live in extreme poverty, why haven't malnutrition rates gone down accordingly? http://econ.st/1eiiRSj

Archive: The world's population is projected to reach 11 billion by the end of the century. Feeding that many people will be a challenge, and it is further complicated by the impact of climate change on agriculture. That is why some people advocate an unusual way to boost the food supply and feed people sustainably: by eating less meat, and more insects http://econ.st/1dioZtL

The oceans are dying. In 1950, about 10 percent of global fish stocks were over exploited. Now, about 60 percent of fish stocks are either over exploited—or have collapsed altogether. The disastrous state of the world's marine fish stocks in 1 minute, 8 seconds http://econ.st/1ebaCYk

How valuable are tax breaks for debt? Most governments say how much mortgage-interest relief costs them in forfeited revenue. But the second type of tax break—interest deductibility for companies and financial firms—is harder to get to grips with. As the financial system has got bigger and fiddlier, no-one really knows how much interest the world's firms pay http://econ.st/1PJ4To0

China should be encouraging its farmers to grow more profitable crops. But it still believes that in order to prevent hunger, the country must produce its staple foods at home rather than rely on unpredictable world markets. View more video from The Economist via: http://econ.st/1A9MNKn

Britain's unpredictable election boggled the pollsters and lifted the FTSE and the pound. Philip Coggan, The Economist's capital markets editor, explains the wobbles http://econ.st/1HkH0Bp

Audio: The magical combination of geeks in T-shirts and venture capital that has disrupted other industries has put financial services in its sights. From payments to wealth management, from peer-to-peer lending to crowdfunding, a new generation of startups is taking aim at the heart of the industry—and a pot of revenues that Goldman Sachs estimates is worth $4.7 trillion http://econ.st/1IClcUP

Britain's former chancellor of the exchequer, Alistair Darling, speaks with Anne McElvoy about what went wrong in 2015. He wants Labour to change its tone and message on business http://econ.st/1cHgUxE

A supportive spouse can help you excel; a jealous or lazy one may hold you back. David Goldberg, husband of Sheryl Sandberg, the number-two executive at Facebook, was one of the former. He gave his own stellar career lower priority than his wife's even more stellar one. It is hardly unusual for a billionaire to have a supportive spouse. Rich men have had them for generations. But people saw the Sandberg/Goldberg household as a model of modern feminism. David Goldberg, the first man of Silicon Valley, died on May 1st, aged 47 http://econ.st/1FikFoH
Jeremy Cliffe and Anne McElvoy discuss the British prime minister's plans to reposition the Tories as the party for working people, starting with doubling child care allowance http://econ.st/1HnNxhw

The former chairman of Britain's Financial Services Authority and author of the forthcoming book "Between Debt and the Devil" explains why private debt, not banks, deepened the financial crisis and continues to cause trouble today http://econ.st/1d1AJRb

Speed kills, cheaply. America's navy is trading explosives for electricity and arming its ships with railguns. A railgun can hurl shells at seven times the speed of sound—three times the muzzle velocity of a conventional naval gun. The fiery plume, visible in the video, is not the result of propellant exploding but of the air itself being ionised by the electric current in the barrel. The first firing tests on board ship will take place next year. If they're succesful, the centuries-long monopoly of gunpowder will have come to an end http://econ.st/1HfUs9y
An #econespresso #quoteoftheday. Get the app http://econ.st/1HfBUpY

Archive: Though increasingly mainstream, tattoos still signal a certain rebelliousness that works against jobseekers. In a study participants were asked to assess job candidates based on their pictures, some of which were altered to add a neck tattoo. Inked candidates consistently ranked lower, despite being equally qualified. By and large the more visible the tattoo, the more "unsavoury" a candidate seemed—even if the boss had one http://econ.st/1EH5wJG
link_name: How a tattoo affects your job prospects

status_message: Audio: In recent years lots of big economies, from Britain to Brazil, have followed America's lead in tightening anti-bribery enforcement. Offences that once drew a slap on the wrist now attract fines in the hundreds of millions of dollars as well as prison terms for palm-greasing managers. It is right that bribery should be punished. But the cost and complexity of investigations are spiralling beyond what is reasonable http://econ.st/1HiZGnU

Audio: Banks are involved in over $400 trillion of transfers every year and extract over $1 trillion in revenues from them. As consumers in both rich and poor countries eschew cash in favour of paying with plastic or, increasingly, online and on their mobiles, that figure could reach over $2 trillion by 2023. But the banks no longer have the field to themselves http://econ.st/1PGBoTP

In the 1960s, mums spent around ten hours a week on childcare, and three times that on housework. Dads spent an average of 40 hours a week doing paid work, and barely did any housework or childcare at all. Then the world changed. But which parent got the better deal? A history of parenting since the 1960s in 1 minute, 9 seconds http://econ.st/1HeJGDg

High earners are better insulated from wage cuts than low earners, as they will tend to have higher net wealth, too. "Roar" has only a whisper of a plot. The real meat lies in the back story, which begins with Tippi Hedren, the star of Alfred Hitchcock's "The Birds". On a film shoot in Africa in 1969, she and Noel Marshall, her husband, spotted a derelict plantation house overrun by lions. Whereas the rest of us might have snapped a photo and run far away, the sight galvanised the couple to make a movie on behalf of Africa's dwindling population of big cats. The result is perhaps one of the purest examples of folly in moviemaking. http://econ.st/1PoBtvh

MESSENGER, one of NASA's probes, has been dutifully orbiting Mercury since 2011, making detailed maps of the entire surface. The spacecraft made many surprising findings about the hitherto mysterious planet, yet its time is nearly up. For it is expected that today, it will crash into the surface it has been studying for so long. Even in death, however, it will make a contribution to science, by gouging a 16-metre crater into the ground http://econ.st/1dwpm3N

It has been one year since the Ebola outbreak in West Africa was recognised. The virus is blood-borne; the world's next big disease could be airborne, which would be much harder to contain—particularly in our globalised, urbanised world. So when the next epidemic breaks out, how do we prevent it from spreading around the world? The Economist explains how to stop the next epidemic http://econ.st/1MTG7Ag

In 2009 the city of Nashville, breaking with its laid-back, guitar-twanging image, staged an "English-only" referendum. The proposal was rejected by 57% to 43%. One puzzle of the campaign was hearing long-time Nashville residents claiming that their ancestors had learned English "instantly". If that were so, it seems odd that 19th-century Nashville supported German-language newspapers for years http://econ.st/1MRj0Gs

Chameleons' colour-changing ways are well-known, but precisely how they do it has remained a mystery until this week. They are far from the only animals with the skill: often deployed for camouflage, in reaction to stress, to warn predators, woo partners, or even to regulate temperature. The Economist explains how animals change colour http://econ.st/1x0ZKod

February 2015 was the wettest month in the region around São Paulo since 1995, with rainfall 36% above the historical average. But the water emergency in South America's biggest metropolis is not over. Because of last year's record drought, water levels in the Cantareira system of reservoirs—which normally supplies nearly half of the area's 20m residents—had sunk to just 5% of capacity http://econ.st/1BAjGwR

John Coltrane, one of the jazz greats, died in 1967, aged 40, from liver cancer. He was a productive artist, often recording several albums in a single year. In some countries International Women's Day is a public holiday. But it is too early to relax efforts to increase equality for working women. Click the link to see our latest interactive glass-ceiling index, which reveals where women have the best chances of equal treatment at work http://econ.st/1BOv3Tx

Boys are being outclassed by girls at both school and university, and the gap is widening. It is a problem that would have been unimaginable a few decades ago. Until the 1960s boys spent longer and went further in school than girls. The reversal is laid out in a report published on March 5th by the OECD, a Paris-based rich-country think-tank.  In all 64 countries and economies in the study, girls outperform boys http://econ.st/1G2UVKk

North Korea's minuscule economy is roughly 40 times smaller than that of its Southern counterpart. Yet an estimate from 2012 values the North's mineral wealth at $10 trillion, 20-odd times larger than that of the South. There is a lesson from the Chinese reform path, in that real, sustained improvements to a decrepit economy are possible only with outside expertise and capital. Yet North Korea's nuclear-weapons programmes darken its relations with the outside world http://econ.st/1zEjeJO
Archive: Mains electricity is scarce and unreliable in Africa, but a solar revolution is afoot. The Economist explains why social power is spreading so fast in Africa http://econ.st/1H74jxN

For centuries, boys were top of the class. These days, girls are scoring higher grades. A new study by the OECD, a club of mostly rich countries, examined how 15-year-old boys and girls performed at reading, mathematics and science. The Economist explains why girls do better at school than boys http://econ.st/1CGNwCP

"Curvology", a new book by David Bainbridge, focuses on the part played by evolution in men's—and women's—understanding and appreciation of the undulations of the female form. Men's and women's bodies differ more than is necessary simply to gestate, bear and nourish children. Why? http://econ.st/1EuV8HM
As Russia reacts to the murder of liberal champion Boris Nemtsov, the country is in danger of becoming more repressive and intolerant than ever http://econ.st/1w8vgjB
This week our correspondents discuss the Dawn spacecraft arriving at Ceres and the perils of security backdoors in software http://econ.st/1DVGlVa
This week our correspondents discuss Warren Buffett's shareholder letter and the 2015 Super Return private-equity shindig http://econ.st/1GTy70P

Archive: View our animated explanation of the mechanics of the human heart, and the devices that can assist it. Read our related article via: http://econ.st/1E9RL8Q
Signs of economic reform are emerging from North Korea. Whether more progress will follow is far from certain http://econ.st/1E0G99H
An #econespresso #quoteoftheday from the poet Alexander Pope. Get the app http://econ.st/1DZCJUD

Buy bonds for income and equities for growth. That is what many a financial adviser will tell you. But it isn't really true anymore. According to Citigroup, the dividend yield on the equity market is higher than the 10-year government bond yield in Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Japan and the UK. In the US, the two yields are neck-and-neck but equity investors can get an extra cashflow boost from buy-backs http://econ.st/1E2exQ1
Archive: With only a split second to react, the keeper has a few ways to increase his odds http://econ.st/1Bcw9bi

The fast food business has seen better times. In 2014 McDonald's annual global revenues fell for the first time in 12 years. People may be buying fewer takeaway burgers, but they have a growing appetite for pizza - from both independent pizzerias and pizza chains. Domino's Pizza, saw its global sales jump by 14% in the last quarter of 2014. The Economist explains the rising dough in the pizza industry http://econ.st/1vFvkqB

For years foreigners accused China of keeping the yuan artificially weak to boost exports. Now, domestic critics say, they are doing just the opposite: keeping the currency artificially strong and, in the process, wounding the economy. But the costs of devaluing the yuan outweigh the benefits for China, for two reasons http://econ.st/1LJjqy5
The oil price has been rising again—but why and will it last? http://econ.st/1DZUyDe
Audio: This week our correspondents discuss research into the purpose of eyelashes and the fitful development of mobile payment systems http://econ.st/1DtHPG3

Today two billion phones are in use worldwide, and this number is expected to double by the end of the decade. To get an idea how much time people will then spend on their smartphones it helps to look at today's young people. Today's #Dailychart shows that, according to Ofcom, those aged between 16 to 24 years use their device nearly four hours a day; those aged between 55 to 64 only half as much http://econ.st/1JQGLT4
Audio: This week our correspondents discuss the latest developments in Greece's euro zone bail-out negotiations and Janet Yellen's testimony to Congress http://econ.st/1JMoru8
Archive: We invite you to imagine a world in which countries could move as easily as people. View our suggestions for a rearranged Europe in this videographic http://econ.st/1FTmzg8

Jean-Paul Sartre, the French thinker and writer, stressed an ever-present emotional element in human thinking that philosophers preoccupied with truth and validity tended to overlook. Sartre's concern, in a phrase, was what it was like to be human. A thorough new biography offers expert analysis into his philosophical arguments http://econ.st/1D3qxwC
Audio: This week our correspondents discuss India's budget, Chicago's mayoral election and a visit by German anti-Islamists to Britain http://econ.st/1AmSxy7
3D printers are not just being used to fabricate small plastic toys.  Researchers are now experimenting with ways to use the technology to build full-scale buildings http://econ.st/1JuSgPQ
British politics is fragmenting. In the run-up to the country's general election, smaller parties like the Greens are squeezing the vote shares of established ones http://econ.st/1vm9AAa

As a rash of measles outbreaks spawns controversy in America, a badly performing flu vaccine is also causing concern. This flu season, the influenza vaccine proved only 23% effective. Last year, it was about 60% effective. Why did the flu shot perform so poorly this season? The Economist explains why flu shots are a lottery http://econ.st/1vl46pe
With the expiration of Greece's euro zone bail-out fast approaching, negotiations in Brussels are steeped in tension and mistrust http://econ.st/17wgasw

"It's always tough to lose," quipped Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, as Debaltseve fell yesterday and rebels raised the flag of Novorossiya, their pseudo-state, over the city centre. Even if the ceasefire is now salvaged, it is a far cry from lasting peace. And Novorossiya's backers still have designs on Mariupol and Kharkiv http://econ.st/17vtVri
Audio: This week our correspondents discuss what happens if there is no deal in Greece, the future of Sony and bankers' pay http://econ.st/1DpIY3V

Archive: Apopo, a charity, is harnessing the enthusiasm for repetitive tasks and acute sense of smell of the Giant African pouched rat to locate landmines and help diagnose TB. Working in Mozambique and Tanzania, they have already cleared large areas of unexploded ordnance and detected TB in hundreds of samples. View our related article via: http://econ.st/19rwA77

Much of the business of Rolls-Royce, a British engineering firm best known for making jet engines, is concerned with propelling things forward, fast. But its annual results, released appropriately enough on Friday 13th, show that the firm has gone into reverse. Revenues fell for the first time in a decade and annual pre-tax profits sagged by 8% to £1.6 billion ($2.5 billion) http://econ.st/1L0DWtC

"When western newspapers lawfully publish words or pictures that cause offence—be they ever so unnecessary, insensitive or disrespectful—western governments should think very carefully before denouncing them." In 2006, we argued that Western leaders were doing a poor job of defending free speech http://econ.st/1zHTLyP

After a week of anger and accusation, our correspondent looks at the reasons behind the delay of Nigeria's presidential elections and what the country must do next http://econ.st/1D5dPCJ
Vietnamese seek better paying jobs abroad. But for poor workers, the cost to go overseas can be staggering and the labour conditions exploitative. View our related article via: http://econ.st/1A3jbKX

Chocolate is blamed for causing cavities and making people fat, but in modest quantities it is actually a healthy treat. The Economist explains why eating chocolate is good for you http://econ.st/1D2Z4Ag

The crisis in Ukraine began with Ukrainians' desire to tilt towards the EU—and Vladimir Putin's determination to stop them. Better than arms, the West must urgently give Ukraine as much aid as it needs to build a state and realise that dream (and as much advice as it takes to ensure the cash is not misspent or stolen). Mr Putin wants Ukraine to be a lesson in the perils of leaning West. It should instead be an exemplar of the rewards http://econ.st/1KO0iAo

On February 12th, the leaders of Russia, Germany, France and Ukraine emerged from a meeting in Minsk unsuccessful. "No good news," said Petro Poroshenko, Ukraine's embattled president, summing up. Today's #Dailychart looks at Russia's growing confrontation with its neighbours and the West, and explains the history leading to today's crisis http://econ.st/16Y8krD

Chocolate is a singularly appropriate gift for a loved one. Providing the recipient does not over-indulge, numerous health benefits may accrue from drinking cocoa or nibbling chocolate confectionery. Both are rich sources of natural antioxidants, thanks to their high level of flavonoids (plant pigments), especially epicatechin http://econ.st/1Ahhk74

The musical chairs model of unemployment says that shocks to nominal GDP—or total spending in the economy—drive unemployment. When nominal GDP falls, there is no longer enough spending to sustain the same number of jobs unless wages fall. To illustrate this, Scott Sumner uses American data to show a close correlation between unemployment, and the ratio of the hourly wage to GDP per person http://econ.st/1CcUj1A

#Dailychart: India's GDP rose by 7.5% in 2014, a shade faster than China's over the same period. India also enjoys a demographic advantage. Whereas China's workforce began to shrink in 2012, more than half of India's current population is younger than 25. India, rather than China, may henceforth be the symbol of rapid emerging market growth http://econ.st/1zsuyIG

Forced to choose between being a cop and running a website for gay men, Ma Baoli resigned from Qinhuangdao's police force in 2012. What measures would improve the state of the world most? Teams of economists commissioned by Bjorn Lomborg estimate completing the treaty currently under negotiation at the World Trade Organisation would bring developing countries $3,426 for every dollar spent. A free-trade deal encompassing China, Japan, South Korea and the ASEAN countries would be worth $3,438 per dollar spent http://econ.st/1z6iIHn
Audio: This week our correspondents discuss some surprising moves from Microsoft and new findings in the science of taste http://econ.st/1yLEC3P

Most histories of the civil war turn inward at the end and examine the war's consequences and legacy for America. Don Doyle's 'The Cause of All Nations' turns outward to show how important America's civil war was to the rest of the world: liberty and democracy defeated slavery and the landed gentry http://econ.st/1tgG3Xn

George Osborne, Britain's chancellor of the exchequer, introduced new savings bonds exclusively for over-65s. The bonds have an artificially high rate: the government will pay 4% to borrow from oldies for three years, versus a three-year gilt yield of around 0.6%. This does not chime well with the chancellor's professed policy priority of keeping Britain's borrowing costs down http://econ.st/1te4ZPf

In the last few decades the Pacific has become the engine room of global trade, far eclipsing the Atlantic. East Asia has turned into a giant factory, sending cheap goods to the United States. It is not the first time in history that the global economy has revolved around the Pacific. Read our related article via: http://econ.st/1CLFXXr
Rule-bound: The expansion of America's regulations, and enforcement against banks http://econ.st/1CmO4f8
After five years of austerity Greeks may elect Syriza, a left-wing populist party, to run their country. If they do, Greece's membership in the euro zone would be under threat http://econ.st/1yP1pMn

There is a good chance that one fish in five sold in a store or served in a restaurant has been caught illegally. That would amount to 26m tonnes of fish a year. The environmental cost of illegal fishing is huge: in the past fifty or so years one in four fisheries has collapsed, largely because of it. The Economist explains how technology could end illegal fishing http://econ.st/1Jt3kHU

Iowa, home to the first presidential caucus, happens to have about 20m pigs http://econ.st/1BpBmNR

The year ahead: Australia's Great Barrier Reef is the largest structure on earth made by living creatures and the world's most extensive coral-reef ecosystem. But rising sea temperatures, acidification, agricultural and industrial runoff are threatening its survival. In 2015 UNESCO will decide whether to add the Great Barrier Reef to the World Heritage Danger List http://econ.st/150GxXd

The recent attacks on Charlie Hebdo and a kosher supermarket have brought the French together. Up to 4m people took peacefully to the streets across France on January 11th, with an estimated 1.6m in Paris alone. No one seemed more surprised by this outpouring than the French themselves. But the unity may not last http://econ.st/1we01wX

To keep up with demand, China now rears (and eats) nearly 500 million pigs a year—more than half of all the swine in the whole world. McDonald's opened its first restaurant in San Bernardino, California in 1948, and it has been spreading the gospel of fast food ever since. Its 35,000 restaurants in 107 countries generated sales of over $89 billion in 2013. But McDonald's has been struggling of late, thanks in part to stiffer competition. In the next 40 years, humans will need to produce more food than they did in the previous 10,000 put together. But with sprawling cities gobbling up arable land, agricultural productivity gains decreasing, and demand for biofuels increasing, supply is not keeping up with demand. Farmers, scientists and entrepreneurs are bursting with ideas. But they need money to make this jump http://econ.st/1KfqXH8

According to Pew Research, the number of American nuns has dropped 72% since 1965 - from 180,000 to 50,000. The number of nuns is also declining much faster in America than elsewhere in the world: in 1970, American nuns represented 16% of the world's religious sisters; today, they're only 7%. This drop makes sense, given the increased opportunities for American women outside the church and the sexism within it http://econ.st/1ruXUJt

British Telecom will not be coming back and ask for a re-merger. Audio: The modern luxury industry rests on a paradox—but is thriving nonetheless, says Brooke Unger. Read our related article via: http://econ.st/12E285W

In tax and contract transparency, there is general acceptance that change is coming, like it or not. And many boards no longer fear that openness is bad for business. In some areas, such as corporate social responsibility, there is evidence that it boosts the share price by signalling that management is tackling hidden risks, says George Serafeim of Harvard Business School http://econ.st/1Gi8qqP
Bores, chores and bedtime stories. How parenting has changed in half a century. Read our related article via: http://econ.st/1GtgfYR

Israel boasts the world's highest concentration of high-tech startups per head. Almost 1,000 new firms are launched every year. But all this entrepreneurial activity is not creating enough jobs as the population grows. It doesn't come as a surprise then that Israelis have become less interested in the super-abundance of startups and more in the scarcity of big successful companies http://econ.st/1BiCMGI

The growth of "marketplace lenders", as the online nearly-banks now prefer to be called, has been exponential. Started in 2007, Lending Club is the biggest, facilitating over $1 billion in loans per quarter. Its rapid progress has fuelled breathless talk of big banks and credit-card peddlers being "disrupted" in the same way taxi companies have been by Uber http://econ.st/1Gi8yq0

The Economist explains how wealth and income inequality have evolved over the past century, and why making access to education more meritocratic could help tackle both problems. Read our related article via: http://econ.st/1BoyjlU
As the Geminids meteor shower reaches its peak, The Economist explains the difference between comets, asteroids and meteors—and the relationship between them http://econ.st/1yHljtm

Audio: Shinzo Abe, Japan's prime minister, seeks re-election, members of parliament in Greece begin voting for a new president and China faces a legal deadline over disputed waters. Our correspondents discuss the week ahead http://econ.st/1zGbMSr
Between 2011 and 2012, many US firms' subsidiaries suddenly disappeared from view. Why? http://econ.st/1GpGC1N

Despite pressure to boycott state elections, voters in the disputed region of Kashmir are flocking to the polls. Their eagerness to vote is not an endorsement of Indian rule. Read our related article via: http://econ.st/1yDg0eo

#Dailychart Advent calendar: In our round-up of the most popular infographics published on our site in the last 12 months, we are at day eleven. This chart from May revealed alcohol consumption across the world. Belarus, Moldova and Russia are the biggest drinkers, according to a report by the World Health Organisation http://econ.st/1zA0Q8H
Which countries buy illegal animal products? What animal products are bought on the illegal wildlife market? Read our related article via: http://econ.st/12uhp9s

After weeks of political infighting, Binyamin Netanyahu called for fresh elections "as soon as possible", signalling the end of his government less than halfway through its four-year term. The break-up coincides with the first economic contraction in five years and a rash of deadly Palestinian attacks. Yet the current infighting is not about either of these issues. The campaign will be dominated by questions of personality http://econ.st/1B0FLnb

"I've been trading since 1992 and I guarantee you this bull market will last." The Chinese stockmarket's trailing price-to earnings ratio of 14 is a 35% discount to its 10-year average. There are, however, troubling signs http://econ.st/1yvFGog

How a tattoo affects your job prospects. Once the preserve of sailors, bikers and rock stars, tattoos are increasingly widespread, particularly among the young. But what do employers think of them? Read our related article via: http://econ.st/1B1SGoM
Which illegal activities generate the most money? http://econ.st/1ytuo99 #econarchive (2013)

Londoners in their 30s are moving out. A record number of 30- to 39-year-olds left the capital in the year to June 2013: a net outflow of nearly 22,000 (and a 25% increase on 2010). They have settled in Birmingham, as well as Manchester, Bristol and Oxford. Mainly they want bigger, cheaper living-space for their children and London's soaring house prices have exacerbated the trend http://econ.st/1G9kfxq

The government will need to do much more to solve Britain's housing problem. On average, 140,000 homes have been built in each of the past four years, far fewer than the 240,000 new houses needed annually. With supply constrained, house prices continue to rise, by 19% in London over the past year. There is an estimated deficit of as many as 1m houses http://econ.st/1scUYw5

Since 2011 the euro zone has stagnated; Lithuania's GDP has grown by 4.3% a year. Its ratio of government debt to GDP is among the lowest in the EU. Moreover, this impressive performance is the result of the sort of root-and-branch reform most euro-zone countries have shirked. So why does Lithuania want to adopt the euro? http://econ.st/1ytpybO

When will robots do to football what computers did to chess? A look at the RoboCup in Brazil, where robots show their football skills and push the boundaries of artificial intelligence. Read our related article via: http://econ.st/1G8Kap1

"Bull market" does not adequately describe the frenzied buying of Chinese shares in the past two weeks, so local media have started calling it a "super-bull". One of the world's worst performers for three consecutive years, China has suddenly shot to the top of the table for all major markets in 2014 http://econ.st/1yt1yk2

When the record of this strange, turbulent period in British politics is written, it will describe a Tory prime minister who rode the tempest, but could not make the weather. If that is the best Westminster can offer, it is disappointing http://econ.st/1zvBxmj

Russia's unacknowledged war in Ukraine did not start with the annexation of Crimea. The precedent was set six years earlier, during a five-day war between Russia and Georgia that resulted in Russia's occupation of the regions of South Ossetia and Abkhazia. On the face of it, Georgia's relationship with Russia has since much improved. Yet it may now be more vulnerable than ever http://econ.st/1ztRz0b

Oddly shaped buildings and unexploded bombs are two reasons it costs more to build in London than any other city. The Economist explains why London is the most expensive city to build in http://econ.st/126K444

The contest between the shalemen and the sheikhs has tipped the world from a shortage of oil to a surplus. Cheaper oil should act like a shot of adrenalin to global growth. There will, of course, be losers. But the overall economic effect of cheaper oil is clearly positive. Read this article, or bookmark it using our 'Timekeeper' feature which allows you to save articles to read later, via http://econ.st/1FUbdEy

On December 3rd George Osborne confirmed that he would not increase the price of fuel duty, an unpopular tax on motorists. Soon Mr Osborne will have overseen the longest freeze of fuel taxes in 20 years. Motorists are rejoicing. But though politically savvy, the chancellor's move is unlikely to last long http://econ.st/1w59GMy

Aficionados of fission have had to wait nearly two decades for another public flotation of a firm operating nuclear power plants. The last one, that of British Energy, was back in 1996, and that troubled company has since been taken over. Now investors have the chance to get in on the action in the hottest place in the global nuclear business: China http://econ.st/1pZ7xiA

#Dailychart Advent calendar: in our round-up of the most popular infographics published on our site in the last 12 months, we are at day five. Today's chart reveals who controls the world's wealth. Wealth is so unevenly distributed, that you need just $3,650 (less debts) to count yourself among the richest half of the world's population. A mere $77,000 brings you among the wealthiest 10%. And just $798,000 puts you into the ranks of the 1% http://econ.st/1G0xdQ3

Britain's fiscal watchdog estimates that growth in both 2010-11 and 2011-12 was 1% lower than it would have been without fiscal austerity. By any standards George Osborne's period as chancellor has been dismal for Britain, says Professor Simon Wren-Lewis of Oxford University http://econ.st/1CMoyCB

Will countries agree on how to tackle climate change in 2015? Join us today for a live video discussion on the year ahead. Daniel Franklin, the editor of "The World in…", will be answering readers' questions on the year ahead from 4pm GMT. You will be able to watch and join the conversation via http://econ.st/1w4SVkA

It has more generals than nearly any other country, but the Thai army was not created to fight wars. Why does it remain the most important political force within Thailand? The Economist explains why the Thai army is so powerful http://econ.st/1FXFPXy

Seven years since the recession began: how America is faring. Today's #Dailychart is an examination of the country's economy from 2008 to today in seven charts. View in full via: http://econ.st/121kIED

Audio: Two campaigners for children's rights and education receive the Nobel Peace Prize, the deadline for America's budget and the conclusion of a conference in Peru on climate change. Our correspondents discuss the week ahead http://econ.st/1pZ23Va

The new weekly issue of The Economist is now available to view via our website and apps: http://econ.st/1pYWrKF

To view the article related to our cover story go to: http://econ.st/1zqch0U

This week's cover preview:
Sheikhs v shale
The new economics of oil 
December 6th – 12th 2014
Read for free via: http://econ.st/1I3JfKr
The FARC guerrilla army recently released a Colombian general they had kidnapped. What lies ahead for the ongoing peace talks? http://econ.st/1A7EDxB

What to look out for in 2015? Join us for a live video discussion this Friday on the year ahead. The editor of The World in, Daniel Franklin, will be answering readers' questions and sharing predictions for 2015. You will be able to watch the conversation via our website: http://econ.st/1znFr0r

What does 2015 have in store? On December 5th, from 4pm GMT, the editor of The World in, our annual predictions publication, will be taking part in a live video discussion on the year ahead. You will be able to view the conversation via our website: http://econ.st/1FNmlVA
Decades after the worst industrial accident in India's history, many residents of Bhopal feel they were abandoned to suffer its toxic effects http://econ.st/15NU6tc

Swiss voters decisively shunned a proposal to drastically curb immigration in a referendum on November 30th, by a 74% to 26% margin. While some Swiss may welcome immigrants, the referendum's defeat owed much to the weaknesses of the specific proposals, and Swiss opposition to immigration is far from over http://econ.st/1zf1Ih0
Does the American economy do better under the Democrats or Republicans? Read our related article via: http://econ.st/1vZvyc1

"If we will not endure a king as a political power, we should not endure a king over the production, transportation and sale of any of the necessaries of life." Are the internet's biggest success stories now simply too big to benefit consumers? http://econ.st/1vZzBoW

Economics is not a profession for the publicity-hungry—except in Argentina. Victoria Giarrizzo of the University of Buenos Aires attributes the wealth of celebrity economists to the volatility of Argentina's economy http://econ.st/122QPod

Air conditioning is a transformative technology. But cooling buildings takes a lot of energy. If an idea dreamed up by Aaswath Raman of Stanford University comes to fruition, that may change. Dr Raman has invented a way to encourage buildings to dump their heat without the need for pumps and compressors. Instead, they simply radiate it into outer space http://econ.st/15Ghhpb
As more and more states allow gay marriage, Jonathan Rauch explains how the revolution in America's attitudes to homosexuality came about and how it affected him http://econ.st/1toMxhs

Renzo Piano, now 77, is the most prolific designer of museums in the world, with more than 21 projects completed so far and more on the drawing board. Mr Piano's tact is highlighted in his latest project, the Harvard Art Museums in Cambridge, Massachusetts. The Italian architect has brought subtlety and tact to a difficult American project http://econ.st/15GdRCM

Rowan Oak stands in a glade near the centre of Oxford, Mississippi. Faded signs and keen volunteers direct visitors round the property in which the writer William Faulkner lived for 32 years. But Rowan Oak needs more spending. Securing sufficient funds to keep historic sites up to scratch is tricky across the South and when federal money runs out, ingenuity is called for http://econ.st/1uQNr5O
After years of criticism, London is beginning to evolve into a 24-hour city. What took it so long? Read our related article via http://econ.st/15HvZw7

Immigration is the quintessential supply-side policy. It expands the labour force, encourages investment and provides taxpayers to support America's growing ranks of the grey-haired. Sadly, Barack Obama's immigration order will have few such benefits http://econ.st/1vsGixA

Sitting pretty? The average recent migrant to Britain from within the EU is in his twenties and costs the NHS less than the average native. On the other hand, over half the British migrants to Spain are over 50, smoke and drink more than their compatriots in Britain and have higher hospitalisation rates than their Spanish neighbours http://econ.st/15GFUlH

Extreme poverty has been halved in the last 25 years, but hunger and malnutrition are far from being eliminated. The Economist explains why so many people are still malnourished http://econ.st/1xQFkIu

Companies are generally not good at changing their chiefs. However, the fact that the CEO will eventually have to go is one of the few "known knowns" in business. Monarchies have always understood the importance of avoiding interregnums: the king is dead, long live the king! Why have some of the world's most sophisticated organisations failed to grasp this simple truth? http://econ.st/1rsrPlE

A decade ago, when France led anti-American opposition to the 2003 Iraq war, the country was seen in Washington as pesky and unreliable. Ten years on, the turnaround is arresting. "France has emerged as one of America's most activist and steady European partners on security issues outside Europe," notes a senior official in the White House http://econ.st/15DJ5dE

If asked why they spied on the computers of their rivals (and allies), the authors of Regin, a sophisticated computer virus that seems to have been designed by a Western government, would presumably echo the proverbial bank robber, and reply "because that's where the secrets are". As the world has gone digital, spying has, too http://econ.st/1ClnF3G

Parenting in America: A message for "helicopter parents". Well-to-do parents worry about two things: the safety of their children and whether they will get into Harvard. They should relax, says our correspondent. Read our related article via http://econ.st/1Clq9z4

Antibiotics everywhere are over-used. As a result, bacteria are growing ever more resistant. Our correspondents discuss the risks of this and what can be done. Read our related article via http://econ.st/1yYu2nD
Bores, chores and bedtime stories. How parenting has changed in half a century http://econ.st/1pjERR2

A regional election hints that Berlusconi's time as leader of Italy's right may be over, and Matteo Salvini's time may have come. Since taking over the Northern League, Mr Salvini has wrenched it to the right. He has focused his rhetoric on unauthorised immigration (which he wants made illegal again), the Roma ("the cause of many problems"), and the euro (which he wants Italy to leave) http://econ.st/1y8WIL9

The world expects a lot of its central bankers. Politicians demand that they control inflation, keep the economy growing and the financial sector stable. But can we rely on central bankers to get things right? They are subject to the same behavioural biases as the rest of us. That is the theme of a recent, thoughtful speech from Andrew Haldane, the Bank of England's chief economist http://econ.st/1C57uHw
Almost three decades after the catastrophe that wrecked it, a proper tomb for reactor number four at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant is nearing completion http://econ.st/1uwomwX

An ageing population could hold down growth and interest rates through several channels. The most direct is through the supply of labour. An economy's potential output depends on the number of workers and their productivity. In both Germany and Japan, the working-age population has been shrinking for more than a decade, and the rate of decline will accelerate in coming years http://econ.st/1vtBo5l
From Instagram: Here is our Monday Economist ad caption to start your week http://econ.st/1peyDlF

In recent weeks China's leaders have been talking up the need to enhance the rule of law. Their aim is to strengthen the Communist Party's grip on power while at the same time ensuring that justice is served more fairly. Many people complain bitterly that courts often pay more heed to the whims of officials than to the law. But in the realm of death, it is the law itself that is the problem http://econ.st/1x5OdNU

For nearly four years the People's Bank of China has classified monetary policy as "prudent", which is supposedly a neutral stance, not too tight, not too loose. In reality it has been tightening, to cool an overheated property market and slow the alarming accretion of debt. The central bank is wary of easing monetary policy, but that is what the economy needs http://econ.st/1tlLhuz

Get your morning head start with The Economist Espresso, our daily app for smartphones. Delivered each weekday before breakfast, it tells you what's on the global agenda in the coming day and, most importantly, what to make of it. Download the app for iPhone or Android now http://econ.st/1Aox3Se

Africa's armies are on a spending spree. Military spending grew 8.3% in 2013 and is up 65% in the past decade, after being flat for the previous 15 years. The continent's biggest spender is Algeria, at $10 billion. Angola spent $6 billion, overtaking South Africa as the biggest spender in sub-Saharan Africa http://econ.st/1F9gkA5

Colombians like to say that the FARC marks time in decades and not years. And with recent peace talks frozen for now, the conflict continues without an end in sight. The Economist explains why the conflict in Colombia endures http://econ.st/1xJsZL2

Labour says it would boost the National Health Service's budget, which sits at £110 billion, by £2.5 billion a year if it wins the election. The Conservatives say they would continue with real-term increases, which have averaged £1 billion a year under this government. The trouble is neither of these pledges would come near to closing the NHS's funding gap, nor would they maintain the current rate of spending when accounting for the ageing population http://econ.st/1xJBnKI

#Dailychart: Executives around the world remain upbeat about the prospects for business but this optimism is on the wane, according to our interactive business-confidence graphic. The balance of respondents who think that global business conditions will soon improve has fallen by 29 percentage points from the beginning of the year to 13 http://econ.st/1r16x90

Atul Gawande on end-of-life care: The leading surgeon and author discusses how doctors in rich countries handle end-of-life care, and why we must not shy away from the question of our own mortality http://econ.st/1F3T1b8

This week's cover preview:
Russia's wounded economy
And the dangers for the rest of the world
November 22nd – 28th 2014
Read for free via: http://econ.st/1vssXXL

The Church of England has cleared the last procedural obstacle to the appointment of women bishops. But if this week is remembered as an important one by church historians, it may be for a different reason: it was the moment when the archbishop of Canterbury finally acknowledged that the Anglican Communion may be impossible to hold together http://econ.st/1voZ0rM

For a film about the man who arguably invented the computer, "The Imitation Game" feels appropriately, though disappointingly, robotic. It shouldn't. It ticks all the right boxes to seduce those who vote for awards. Yet there is something altogether too languid about this piece http://econ.st/1vlsXc5

Paul Haggis's films have always divided opinion and his latest, "Third Person", is no different. Powered by a stellar cast including Liam Neeson, Mila Kunis, Adrien Brody and Olivia Wilde, it deals with writing, love and trust. Mr Haggis spoke to The Economist about why he courts controversy, and the price of creativity. Read via: http://econ.st/1wQy3rL

Kazakhstan has turned geography to advantage as China plans a "New Silk Road". With Chinese manufacturers moving inland, getting their products to European markets has become more complicated. The journey back to the coast and halfway around the world by sea takes up to 60 days, Kazakhstan offers a backdoor route http://econ.st/1xLs1M5
The end of the population pyramid: our live #Dailychart shows that the shape of the world's demography is changing http://econ.st/1oZc3NK
The world's poor need the stability and security that banks have traditionally offered, but increasingly they do not need banks to provide it http://econ.st/1A7i5jn

Fairy tales have come a long way. The history of these wonder tales, as they are sometimes called, is a favourite subject of Marina Warner, a literature professor at Birkbeck College in London and All Souls, Oxford. In "Once Upon a Time" she draws together her research, touching on anthropology, psychoanalysis, literary analysis and an expansive history http://econ.st/1vhvt30
Rule-bound: An animated infographic showing the expansion of America's regulations, and enforcement against banks http://econ.st/1ume7i4

Four centuries ago the Pacific Ocean was central to the global economy. It was not to last. As the centre of global gravity shifted to the Atlantic, the Pacific became a vast backwater of trading monopolies brutally enforced by gunboat. But now, as our special report this week asserts, the Pacific's time has come. Why? http://econ.st/1EUDdch

The audience at the Royal Festival Hall on November 8th enjoyed a musical experience that is rather rare in London: Russian music performed by Russian players. It was delivered by the St Petersburg Philharmonic Orchestra, which has returned to Britain with an all-Russian programme, assisted by a solo violinist, Maxim Vengerov, who is also from Russia http://econ.st/1wIZ93O
Our correspondents discuss the L'Aquila verdict and worldwide clampdowns on the dark web http://econ.st/11lb6VM

The economy of Ukraine is a mess. By year's end it will have shrunk by 10%. The east of the country, where the conflict with Russian separatists has raged, has seen billions of dollars' worth of damage. The West, despite big promises of help, has been woeful in its response. Unless there is a change of course soon, Ukraine's economy could collapse http://econ.st/1usxE1B

In the last few decades the Pacific has become the engine room of global trade, far eclipsing the Atlantic. East Asia has turned into a giant factory, sending cheap goods to the United States. It is not the first time in history that the global economy has revolved around the Pacific. Read our related special report via http://econ.st/1zr2kR7

The bits of the electromagnetic spectrum dedicated to communications are fairly crowded. Engineers are always on the lookout for new ways to pack more information onto them. A promising way to pack a lot more information into a given slice of the spectrum has passed a significant test this week, by beaming images of a few famous Austrians across Vienna http://econ.st/1va2bU8

Nearly 30 studies from various countries show that children who are regularly spanked become more aggressive themselves, as both children and adults. They are also more likely to be depressed or take drugs, even after correcting for other factors. Still, 81% of American parents believe that spanking is sometimes necessary. That is more than in many other rich countries http://econ.st/1zl0nFC
New research from Switzerland may explain what causes the feeling of a spooky presence. The Economist explains why we feel ghosts http://econ.st/1xDW49o
China's atheist Communist Party is faced with the growing popularity of religion. Read our related article via http://econ.st/1zmyltz

Since Republicans took control of the House of Representatives in 2010 bitter battles with Senate Democrats and Barack Obama produced a near-default on the national debt, a white-knuckle fiscal cliff and a 16-day government shutdown. Now that Republicans also control the Senate, they have a chance to improve on that record http://econ.st/145siQ8

We recently launched a daily edition of The Economist via our Espresso app. More and more people are reading news on their smartphones, on the go. Should this change the way content is produced? The Economist's digital editor, Tom Standage, will be answering questions on our new app tomorrow from 4pm UK time. Pose yours with #Econespresso via http://econ.st/1sDfcyM and download the app for iPhone: http://econ.st/14cOk3i or Android: http://econ.st/1sDfeqz

Barack Obama, who just after his re-election in 2012 became the first sitting American president to visit Myanmar, is due back there for a regional summit on November 12th and 13th. He will find that the bubble of euphoria about the country's reforms has burst. Replacing it is a sombre new realism http://econ.st/1wAqXLB
Gluten-free goods are a booming business. So what is gluten and is it really that bad for you? Read our related article via http://econ.st/1xHq2aD

Today is the deadline for Russia to appeal against a record-breaking arbitration award: $50 billion, won at a Dutch tribunal in July by Yukos's former majority owners, for the expropriation of the oil company in 2004-07. For more content like this, download The Economist Espresso, our new daily app http://econ.st/1xoNYjM

A "merry-go-round of data that isn't really data." A profusion of flawed international rankings on everything from education to modern-day slavery risks misleading policy makers and the public alike http://econ.st/1AUbM3M
A textbook case of price-gouging: An animated infographic showing why university books in America cost so much. Read a related article via: http://econ.st/1ss3wOz

There is a valuable tool that epidemiologists would like to use to track Ebola and help stamp it out: data from mobile phones. Yet despite talks among researchers, phone companies, governments - and even UN agencies and the GSMA, the mobile-industry's trade association - the records have not yet been released. Why not? http://econ.st/10Lr36b
From our Instagram: Here is our Monday Economist ad caption to start your week http://econ.st/143IaTe

In the swing state of Ohio, the Republican governor, John Kasich, secured re-election on November 4th. Mr Kasich, who is 62, is proud of his conservative achievements. He is prouder still of what prosperity enables him to do. In the governor's telling, conservatism must have a moral purpose http://econ.st/1zzV8oI

"The best way for West Germans to help the East is to stand back, hands in pockets, until Mr Krenz accepts a free-market democracy. He will probably have to." 25 years ago today, the Berlin Wall came down. Our editorial from 1989 was to prove farsighted. http://econ.st/1uLLEox

Alix Christie's debut novel puts a human face on the invention of the printing press and brings to the fore a little known third actor in the creation of Johannes Gutenberg's world-changing Bible http://econ.st/1y9sUNe
Obituary: Joan Quigley, astrologer to the Reagans, died on October 21st, aged 87 http://econ.st/1zAgFh3

Download the app for iPhone or Android now http://econ.st/1ye0iT6

Property prices continue to climb in London and in other major European cities, but Berlin has defied the trend. The Economist explains why it is cheaper to buy property in Berlin than in other European capitals http://econ.st/1uFHy1U

Eric Schmidt, executive chairman at Google, is featuring in a remake of our 1996 advert with Henry Kissinger. In the new version, Mr Schmidt gets into a lift with a nervous member of staff and leaves him lost for words. 

Since our first version of the video in the nineties, The Economist has grown from being a print-only newspaper to being available online, in apps and now also in a daily edition via Economist Espresso. Visit our website or download any of our apps via http://econ.st/1uG89vD

With the story of the last years of J.M.W. Turner, arguably the greatest ever landscape painter, Mike Leigh may have created the ultimate biopic for people who don't usually like such films. The Economist spoke to Mr Leigh about the pull of the 19th century and how digital filming helped create Turner-esque filmscapes http://econ.st/1t1IR3P

Welcome back to Washington
