At first glance, DigitalGlobe, an American satellite-imagery firm, paints an upbeat picture for investors. In its most recent quarterly earnings, released last week, the company met analysts' predictions, producing only a very slim loss of around $100,000. However, on closer inspection, the firm is not quite as healthy as it may first appear http://econ.st/10Pn0Hc

The data we generate online has spawned a complex new ecosystem of firms tracking, interpreting and selling our data to advertisers. This raises privacy concerns for consumers. Read our related article via: http://econ.st/1wxHArn
The Republicans win the Senate, and in the end it was a massacre. See our map with the latest results http://econ.st/1tZ4N4G
Can you break a hundred? Our videographic shows how the use of cash has changed in America. Read our related article via http://econ.st/1x2bEKB

Archive: You're sitting on a plane waiting for a transatlantic flight when Henry Kissinger, famed for his intellect, takes the seat next to you. Ready for a good chat?

Back in 1996, when The Economist was a print-only newspaper, Henry Kissinger, the former US secretary of state, made his first ad appearance in a British television commercial with The Economist.

America's mid-term elections on Tuesday could throw the balance of power to Republicans in Congress. Our correspondents analyse the battles ahead. For more on the US elections, view our elections hub via: http://econ.st/1xTOEwo

On November 2nd the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) said that it was extremely likely that climate change is the product of human activity. The Economist explains why scientists are (almost) certain that climate change is man-made http://econ.st/1xSxlfk
Videographic: How advertising spending has changed in America. Read our related special report via http://econ.st/1wSESf1

John Key, New Zealand's prime minister, is bent on coming up with a new flag for New Zealand, one in which Britain's Union Jack will no longer feature. Instead, he says, the flag will "scream New Zealandness". To The Economist Mr Key explained that changing the flag is "about our place in the world and how we see ourselves…confident, outward-looking, multicultural." http://econ.st/1nUuySW

How to print a house

3D printers are not just being used to fabricate small plastic toys.  Researchers are now experimenting with ways to use the technology to build full-scale buildings http://econ.st/1wSEb5e
This week's KAL's cartoon http://econ.st/1nTS3vm

"One country, two systems", the formula supposed to guarantee Hong Kong's autonomy under Chinese sovereignty, was first devised for Taiwan. But it has never held much appeal there, and China's refusal to cede to the demands of pro-democracy protesters in Hong Kong comes as no surprise. But the confrontation makes it harder to enthuse Taiwan about unification with the mainland http://econ.st/1wO9jFq

Sweaty palms and pounding hearts may not be for everyone, but the physical and psychological effects of fear can make it a pleasant experience. The Economist explains why we like being scared http://econ.st/1wNS7OX

The food industry is finding that there is no longer much money to be made in making meat-free products. Sales of alternatives to meat have flattened in America in real terms since 2008; in Britain they have plunged by a third. Consumer demand for products without gluten, however, is rising rapidly http://econ.st/1wmUAi9

Should cyclists obey traffic laws?

Urban Americans are finally taking up bicycling in a big way. That's sparking heated debate about the rules of the road. Read a related article via: http://econ.st/1nT8Q1E

Owning a Ferrari is the dream of many a petrolhead, but for most drivers the Italian supercars are priced well beyond their reach. Next year owning part of the company may be a more realistic prospect. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) said on October 29th that it would spin-off Ferrari in 2015. Sergio Marchionne, FCA's rumpled boss, said that it was time for the two car companies to pursue "separate paths" http://econ.st/1wG4RVS

What drives grade inflation at Ivy League colleges

Grade point averages have soared at American universities. But are students actually getting smarter? Read our related article via: http://econ.st/1zfoiZU

The protection racket was one of the first businesses the Sicilian mafia entered into. Mafiosi have shaken down firms on the island for over 150 years. Those who have stood up to them were often ostracised by other business owners and then murdered. But a clever grassroots campaign, emphasising the commercial benefit of refusing to pay the "pizzo", caught the organised criminals by surprise http://econ.st/1u00Iir

Steven Pinker on bad and good writing

The psychologist and word-usage expert has produced a style guide with cognitive sensibilities called "The Sense of Style". Read our review via http://econ.st/1tf9WFL

#Dailychart: The Economist has recalculated the result of Brazil's presidential election, weighting it by the 27 states' GDP rather than their population of eligible voters. If reais of output went to the polls instead of citizens (which they thankfully do not in a democracy), Mr Aécio Neves would beat Dilma Rousseff by 53% to 47% http://econ.st/ZTpDXb

The benefits of getting rid of cash

Technology like digital wallets and electronic payments are becoming more accessible. So do we even need coins and notes any more? Read our related article via http://econ.st/1sv18pX

After a tight and tetchy race, marked by innumerable twists and turns, Brazil's left-wing president, Dilma Rousseff, was re-elected on October 26th to a second four-year term with 51.6% of valid votes. Here is how Brazil voted, state by state http://econ.st/1tYgBGf
The Devil's in the deterrant: countries with citizens that believe strongly in hell have lower crime rates #econarchive (2012) http://econ.st/1vHAJLm
From papyrus to pixels: the digital transformation of the way books are written, published and sold has only just begun. A beautiful essay on the future of the book http://econ.st/1woD511
Tracking the journey of a virus: our interactive map of the Ebola outbreak http://econ.st/1wmpNln

Every urbanite grumbles about the price of housing. But some have more cause to complain than others. New York, London and Beijing are heart-palpitatingly expensive. Perth, Bangkok and Rome are more moderately priced. Today's interactive #Dailychart reveals how much city-dwellers overpay for housing. View and interact via http://econ.st/1D6MsUe

Wars are defined by their winners and losers. But some conflicts remain frozen for decades. What makes these disputes so intractable? The Economist explains what defines a frozen conflict http://econ.st/1D5LGqr

Since the late 1990s the number of bicycle rickshaws in London has swelled. As they are unregulated, with no set fare or formal licensing structure, precise figures are hard to come by. Mostly they cater for drunken clubbers or tourists who cannot find their way round the city. Plenty of Londoners dislike the pedicabs. Despite this, rickshaws have proved hard to get rid of http://econ.st/121a3u9

The digital revolution

The digital revolution offers great advantages but it also threatens the jobs of low and mid-skilled workers. As computers become smarter, so too must humans. Read our related article via http://econ.st/1wmS4Ze

America is the only rich country that still relies on magnetic strips and signatures for most credit-card transactions. It is also the only one in which the market in counterfeit credit cards is still consistently growing. The Economist explains why America has been slow to adopt modern credit-card technology http://econ.st/12hGowM

This week's cover preview:
Europe's economy
October 25th – 31st 2014
Read for free via: http://econ.st/1wmd4iM

Japan is still a land where you can't move to the rhythm in a nightclub after midnight. This is despite years of campaigning by Japan's youth. Certainly no one expected that the country's prime minister, Shinzo Abe, a social conservative, would change things. Yet the government is about to allow late-night dancing with a new parliamentary bill http://econ.st/1Dwndws

#Dailychart: Winter is the deadliest season. That is common knowledge. But it was not always so - at least, not for nobles, the group for whom records are most complete. A working paper shows that summer used to be much worse. There are probably two reasons for this. One is the medieval nobles' penchant for warfare. The other is disease http://econ.st/12ceiTI

What lies beneath: 33 years ago this month, a Soviet submarine armed with nuclear torpedoes ran aground in Sweden. Last week, sightings off the southern Stockholm archipelago have raised suspicions of an incursion by another Russian submarine http://econ.st/1sPjxBb

Order and decay

The political scientist Francis Fukuyama explains how the West has developed strong states while the Middle East and Africa continue to struggle. Read our review of Mr Fukuyama's book "Political Order and Political Decay" via http://econ.st/1wkagTh
What is the most trusted news source in America? It's not the New York Times, PBS or the BBC, according to a new report from Pew Research... http://econ.st/12agA5F

Trending: Buzludzha was once the futuristic, flying-saucer shaped headquarters of the Communist Party in Bulgaria, but it is now a semi-ruin after being left to rot. There is a haunting beauty in the building's decline, and people have recently been finding creative uses for the space. View more on Bulgaria via our topics section http://econ.st/1vIfk4N

On the third anniversary of the death of Colonel Muammar Qaddafi, Libya's former ruler, the country is violently split. It has two governments and two parliaments. Both the capital, Tripoli, and the second city, Benghazi, are controlled by Islamist militia groups of various stripes. Our #Dailychart looks at a country on the edge http://econ.st/1wfOzUc

The new Museum of the History of Polish Jews honours the way that Jews lived, and prospered in Poland for 1,000 years, rather than focusing solely on the suffering of the Holocaust http://econ.st/1FqZ8t0
New evidence suggests that bilingual people are better able to focus on demanding mental tasks despite distractions http://econ.st/1Fqc42h

Airbnb, a short-term property letting service, has prompted a gold rush. What began as a platform for homeowners with spare rooms to make a bit of pocket money on the side, is becoming overrun with property entrepreneurs looking for lucrative short term gains. The market is also getting more crowded with competition coming from upstarts such as Roomorama and HomeAway http://econ.st/1rEYZHP

On October 13th Jean Tirole was awarded the Nobel prize in economics for his work on "industrial organisation". Mr Tirole began publishing in the 1980s, when it quickly became clear that new, liberalised industries might not form perfectly competitive markets. He developed a novel way of thinking about the difficulties regulators face managing such markets http://econ.st/1F4jjg1

Abroad and at home, a rising chorus is criticising Germany's chancellor, Angela Merkel, for her economic policies. Yet Mrs Merkel is still the country's most popular politician. In a poll this month, 79% thought that she was doing a good job, a number that her American, British or French counterparts can only dream of  http://econ.st/1xVB7oV

Every year Neiman Marcus, a posh department store, offers a Christmas catalogue stuffed with ideas to empty even the fattest wallet. For $425,000 you can attend the Vanity Fair Oscar party. The costliest item in this year's book is the "House of Creed Bespoke Fragrance Journey". For $475,000 you can fly to Paris and have a master perfumier create a scent that perfectly suits you http://econ.st/1xVKncz

How to stop the spread of Ebola

The worst outbreak in history of the deadly Ebola virus is gathering pace. What can be done to keep it at bay? View our video to find out and read more on Ebola via our related article: http://econ.st/1yJXmkO

Are travellers becoming less courteous, or are people just becoming more ill-tempered? A survey by Expedia, an online travel firm, asked around 8,500 travellers what annoyed them most about others' mobile habits. What people find most egregious of all, it suggests, is someone making a call on their speakerphone http://econ.st/100aGDj
Harnessing the types of reaction that power the sun into limitless, clean energy is said to be always 30 years away. This firm says it can be done in just ten http://econ.st/1sPRrXT

There is nothing to stop Major League Baseball's plutocrats from hiring the finest minds money can buy, just as they sign the best athletes. Big-market clubs are starting to join the cult of the genius general managers http://econ.st/1w2nSCD

Symptoms of the Ebola virus may manifest themselves in a day, or they may wait weeks. Some of the sick weather the storm, but various combinations of symptoms kill about 70% of those who get ill http://econ.st/1sMv3yt

A century ago, Chinese migrants numbered about 100,000 in India. By one estimate, barely 4,000 people now remain, about half of them in Kolkata's Chinatown. A plan exists to salvage the remaining Chinese buildings in Kolkata, partly in the hope of persuading the last Chinese to stay http://econ.st/1v1RVe9
Australia's new anti-terror laws are far more draconian than those in Britain or America. The impact on personal freedom will be far higher http://econ.st/1wQ458s

Why eating insects makes sense

About two billion people already eat bugs. Mexicans enjoy chilli-toasted grasshoppers, Thais tuck into cricket stir-fries and Ghanaians snack on termites. Insects offer crunchy solutions to boosting the food supply and feeding people sustainably. Watch our video for three reasons why eating bugs makes sense, and find out more via our related article: http://econ.st/1qBQEFq

This week's cover previews:
Worldwide ex Latin America: The war on Ebola
Read via: http://econ.st/1yGP8Ka 
Latin America: Why Brazil needs change
Read via: http://econ.st/1ryJxNd 
October 18th – 24th 2014

Rail services between the south of Sri Lanka and its battle-scarred northern peninsula resumed on October 13th, for the first time in 24 years. Sri Lanka's president said that the reopened track will serve as a bridge to connect the north and south, and "to win the hearts of the people". The first job is done. The president has yet to prove his commitment to the second http://econ.st/1EXzqvM

The price of insuring Venezuela's bonds against default has risen by 80% over the past two months - suggesting they are the world's riskiest. Venezuela's main rival for the title of riskiest sovereign debtor is Ukraine, rated worst in class by all big credit-rating agencies http://econ.st/1tmfhg3
This Swiss banker, Raoul Weil, has just gone on trial for aiding tax evasion http://econ.st/1sIcdc2

Anti-Muslim sentiment may be alive and well in America, but there are good reasons to believe it won't last. Already there are encouraging signs: Muslims appear to be far better integrated in America than in Europe, as measured by their share of non-Muslim friends and by the intermarriage rate http://econ.st/1sJ1A8G
There are approximately 35 million millionaires in the world. That's just 0.7% of the adult population. But collectively, they hold 44% of the world's total wealth http://econ.st/1qonMAh

Of his first play, Tennessee Williams wrote: "probably no man has ever written for the theatre with less foreknow-ledge of it." Yet he must have done something right, as he became America's most radical 20th-century playwright http://econ.st/1qjrk6S

Which school offers the world's best business programme? Today's #Dailychart is our ranking of full-time MBA programmes. For the fourth time in five years, the University of Chicago's Booth School of Business tops the list. Fifteen of the top 20 schools are American. However, HEC Paris, the top European school, has climbed four places to fourth http://econ.st/1z4wg99

At least 331 Ukrainian soldiers and civilians have died since September 5th, when the government and the rebels agreed to stop fighting. The so-called ceasefire was but one point of a 12-step peace plan hashed out by Russia's Vladimir Putin and Ukraine's Petro Poroshenko. The broad contours seemed to satisfy all parties. But the devil is in the detail, and implementation has faltered http://econ.st/1quU8Zh

When it was discovered in 2000, the Kashagan oilfield in Kazakhstan's waters in the northern Caspian Sea was the world's biggest oil find in three decades. By now it was supposed to be pumping out 1.2m barrels a day (mbd), enough to meet Spain's entire consumption. But the project, whose name sounds unfortunately like "cash all gone", went spectacularly awry http://econ.st/1t5lcWG

In what feels like the latest instalment of a sagging film franchise, a row is looming over France's budget. Under euro-zone rules, France is meant to reduce its budget deficit below 3% of GDP by next year, a deadline that has already been extended twice. But last month it announced that it would do no such thing http://econ.st/1pVNQm6

Once, graduates of the world's leading business schools wanted nothing more than to climb an investment bank's greasy pole, with the vast riches this promised. But with bonus cuts and cultural shifts, banks are being shunned in favour of consulting and technology firms http://econ.st/1thxYS5
This week's KAL's cartoon http://econ.st/1t5Cfb7

The sky has never looked brighter for the world's big planemakers. Airbus and Boeing have bulging order books, with a combined backlog of 10,000 aircraft worth nearly $1 trillion at list prices. The makers of engines, electronic systems and bits of airframe will also be rubbing their hands at the prospect of years of guaranteed business. But can suppliers cope with the ramp-up in production? http://econ.st/1pIC1zB

School vouchers are a divisive subject in America. To settle the debate, many have looked to Sweden, where vouchers were introduced in 1992. The results there have been cited as both a case for and against vouchers. So, what has been the actual effect of this Swedish experiment? http://econ.st/1s1VyzD

The International Monetary Fund has released the full update to its fall World Economic Outlook. Back in January the IMF thought the world might manage growth of 3.7% this year. That dropped to 3.6% in April, to 3.4% in July, and to 3.3% in the new report. If growth is written down any more then this year's performance will come in below that in 2013, of 3.3%. The news could get worse in future http://econ.st/1oOP5Dy

Under the PetroCaribe programme, ten members of the Caribbean Community buy oil from Venezuela. Described as "more noose than lifeline", the possibility of the programme eventually ending leaves many Caribbean countries vulnerable http://econ.st/1vMnrMq
On October 8th, Britain opened the Space Weather Operations Centre, to monitor and forecast off-world weather. But how does weather exist in space? #econarchive http://econ.st/1EuiyN4

Choirs sang in Moscow yesterday as people queued for hours to get T-shirts bearing his image. He was compared to Greek heroes and exhibitions were opened in his name. What was the special occasion? Vladimir Putin's birthday, of course http://econ.st/1oRbu2Z

The UK Independence Party (UKIP), is a supple gymnast. Its boozy, cheerful leader, Nigel Farage, can bend towards Labour and Tory voters simultaneously. Eventually he will pull a muscle http://econ.st/1EogV3i

Ollie Dabbous leapt into the limelight as soon as his eponymous restaurant opened in an unprepossessing corner of London in 2012. A Michelin star followed less than a year later and now he has a lavishly illustrated cookbook which juxtaposes grim industrial detail with exquisite dishes of identifiable simple ingredients http://econ.st/1trGYhG

In the end, Microsoft fooled everyone. The replacement for its widely disparaged Windows 8 operating system turned out to be not Windows 9, as expected, but Windows 10. No explanation, other than marketing waffle, was given as to why the company should skip a release number. Within minutes, various presumed reasons had gone viral http://econ.st/1s2NCOC

After 18 months of political turbulence, which saw four governments fall, the last thing Bulgaria needed was another inconclusive election. And yet the snap parliamentary poll on October 5th produced a highly fragmented parliament that will do little to address the myriad problems of the European Union's poorest member state http://econ.st/1oJLmXT

Even Germans - wary savers and investors - are chafing at the euro zone's ultra-low interest rates. Many of them are turning to a more daring and yet somehow comforting investment: small bonds issued by Germany's medium-sized Mittelstand companies http://econ.st/1s1gwP2

Pentecostal churches are booming in Nigeria, indeed across much of Africa. The satellite television channel of the man they call the Prophet, Temitope Balogun ("T.B.") Joshua, airs prophecies live to millions worldwide. The international reach of Mr Joshua became tragically apparent on September 12th, when a six-storey guesthouse used by his church suddenly collapsed http://econ.st/1yFGWem

"HP managers gush about the inherent synergies among the units - such as bundling software on PCs, or selling both servers and the devices that access them. But the rationales sound slightly contrived." In 2006, we predicted that Hewlett-Packard would be broken up. Today it announced it would split itself in two #econarchive (2006) http://econ.st/1s19DNX
Malaria is present in some parts of Latin America. But thanks to the US Army, in and around the Panama Canal Zone the risk of catching the disease is low. Why? http://econ.st/Z8iDF8

Most animals move about - that is what the word means. But it's not much use moving around if you don't know where you are. This year's Nobel prize for physiology or medicine, therefore, was awarded to three scientists who have helped work out how mammals do this. Between them, three scientists, discovered two sets of cells, in two neighbouring parts of the brain, which tell that brain where it is http://econ.st/1s0LDKA

Manuel Valls, France's Socialist prime minister since March, is engineering a strong shift in his country's economic policy. Mr Valls heads the most reformist government France has seen for many years. But might the beneficiaries be Nicolas Sarkozy and Marine Le Pen? http://econ.st/1vAaEvt

Since becoming South Korea's finance minister in July, Choi Kyung-hwan has been busy. First came a 41 trillion won ($39 billion) stimulus package. Now Mr Choi is trying to pep up the economy further by getting South Korean firms to spend more on wages and dividends. Mr Choi's scheme will tax companies' cash piles on the grounds that corporate stinginess is holding the country back http://econ.st/1rz2Zhz

As Brazilians prepare to pick their president on October 5th, the race is up in the air. The only certainty is that the left-wing incumbent, Dilma Rousseff, will emerge ahead of her rivals in the first round of voting. But despite Ms Rousseff's recent gains in opinion polls it seems unlikely that she will secure an outright majority and thus avoid a run-off http://econ.st/1pWGf5U

A new report gives an account of the conditions of life in 25 countries since 1820. You would expect that the world of the Qing dynasty, Tsar Nicholas I and the British East India Company would be more unequal than today's. Yet in China, Thailand, Germany and Egypt, income inequality was about the same in 2000 as it had been in 1820 http://econ.st/1vB5xfJ

On his visit to America, India's prime minister, Narendra Modi, took the country by storm. The easy bit of Mr Modi's trip involved energising the Indian-American diaspora and generating publicity back home. But the harder part involved rehabilitating his reputation with America's leaders http://econ.st/ZAI1om

Hong Kong's protests are brave and important, posing the biggest challenge from the streets to China's government since Tiananmen Square in 1989. But in absolute numbers they are small. Today's #Dailychart shows how Hong Kong's protests stack up against other displays of people power since early 2011 http://econ.st/1vEIlNq

In the smouldering economic landscape of the euro zone, the future is riding on two men. France's prime minister, Manuel Valls, is leading the most reformist government in years. Italy's prime minister, Matteo Renzi, is also talking of change. But the Vallenzi are open to the same criticism: that as far as reform goes, they are all mouth and no trousers http://econ.st/1oFmXCI

Argentina could do worse than listen to the economic guru, Puff Daddy. As he says, "It's all about the Benjamins". Had the country's government resolved its debt situation, it might now be able to tap international markets for hard currency. Instead it's struggling, and fudging the numbers is certainly "No Way Out" http://econ.st/1ryVSai

Using a question mark in conjunction with an exclamation mark or two can help convey the urgency of a question. But the interrobang, a question-exclamation hybrid, is more than 50 years old, but has never quite caught on. Could this be its moment? (Could it‽) http://econ.st/1mUddZU

Bill Gross, often dubbed the "Bond King", had a shock departure from his firm, PIMCO, on September 26th. His flagship "Total Return" fund earned a return of 164% over the past 15 years, far above the industry's average of 116%. So what prompted him to leave? http://econ.st/1qOh9X7

Bulgaria has changed governments four times in the last 18 months. On October 5th Bulgarians will vote for another one. After nearly two years of political instability, which began after anti-poverty protests led to the resignation of the centre-right government in February 2013, the poorest member of the European Union seems to have come full circle http://econ.st/1oiYjI3
Obituary: William Oliver, champion of the world's wild pigs, died on September 10th, aged 67 http://econ.st/1svcH79

SheTaxis, a new car service, lets female passengers insist on female drivers, and vice versa. But it faces two speed bumps. One is practical. Demand has been so great that the firm has had to decelerate its launch until it can recruit 500 drivers. And the other obstacle is legal. By employing only female drivers, SheTaxis is obviously discriminating against men http://econ.st/1ojhkdf

India was as badly shaken as any emerging market last year. But it is now on a sounder footing. The economy grew at 5.7% year-on-year in the second quarter. That is not a sparkling rate for an economy that until a few years ago was growing at 9% a year, but is a good deal better than in most places. Yet the impetus for reform has slowed http://econ.st/1swNcSK

On September 25th, Narendra Modi, India's prime minister, called together hundreds of diplomats, business leaders, journalists, ministers and others to a swanky hall in Delhi to launch his latest marketing push. Mr Modi is trying to persuade investors that India is an attractive place to do manufacturing. Yet, as he suggests, achieving that requires progress in a host of areas http://econ.st/1stvoYD

Cupid's arrow does not always fly true, as investors in the Edinburgh-based online matchmaking service of the same name discovered on September 23rd. The company, which runs subscription-based dating websites, announced £3m ($4.9m) in pre-tax losses for the six months ending June. But there is no shortage of lovelorn singletons and free dating services are booming http://econ.st/1pd7HwU

Thousands of students in Hong Kong are boycotting classes this week to lie on lawns outside government headquarters and discuss topics such as "post-totalitarianism" and George Orwell's book "Animal Farm". The boycott is in response to a decision by China's legislature to impose restrictions on the choosing of candidates in elections for the territory's leader that are due in 2017 http://econ.st/1peENfQ

The new weekly issue of The Economist is now available to view via our website and apps: http://econ.st/1reOFfc

To view the article related to our cover story go to: http://econ.st/1oj3APQ

The Sarko show is back. Half of France is mesmerised, the other half dismayed. Nicolas Sarkozy's campaign for the leadership of the conservative UMP party begins tonight at a rally in Lambersart in northern France. Although he has not confirmed that he will run for a second presidential term in 2017, nobody doubts his intentions http://econ.st/1ysyajA

This week's cover preview:
Mission relaunched
September 27th – October 3rd 2014 
Read for free via: http://econ.st/1qxQ6zh

Ludwig van Beethoven lived in a remarkable time. His youth was steeped in the Enlightenment, to be followed in short order by revolution and war all over Europe. With a lightness of touch that makes history come to life, a new book explores the life of arguably the most famous composer who ever lived http://econ.st/1tZ4Hts

Hotel guests in low-crime areas should feel safe leaving their belongings in their rooms. But thefts do happen. Just how often is a difficult question, however, as it turns out that statistics on hotel theft are surprisingly hard to find http://econ.st/1rlaCIk
Is another long life of Napoleon really necessary? On three counts, the answer given by Andrew Roberts's impressive book, "Napoleon the Great", is an emphatic yes http://econ.st/XUw378

The one thing to be said about Elon Musk is that, no matter the challenge, he has always delivered. But has Mr Musk bitten off more than he can chew with his electric car for the masses? http://econ.st/1uhYF8Q
Brazil's presidential election has been turned upside-down. Polls show Marina Silva beating either of her rivals in a run-off. How did Ms Silva get out in front? http://econ.st/1sXs3vj

On September 14th Heineken, the world's third biggest brewer by volume, said it had rejected a takeover proposal from SABMiller, the number two. SAB seems to have been trying to defend itself against a possible takeover by AB InBev, the biggest brewer, which was said to be talking to bankers about raising £75 billion ($121 billion) to buy its rival http://econ.st/1BQLaxK

How long does it take to become a millionaire? The answer is strikingly different, depending on where you try. America creates the swiftest millionaires, and also the most. South of the border, Mexicans can expect to toil for three centuries to earn the same #econarchive http://econ.st/1ylQ1bQ

Historians will struggle to put dates on Russia's murky war against Ukraine. It had no official start and no formal end. Ukraine never formally declared itself under attack, so it cannot formally admit its defeat. But that does not make defeat any less real. After six months of fighting, Ukraine has lost at least 3,000 men and control over a swathe of territory in the east http://econ.st/1yjkWWt

It is not surprising that some visitors were taken aback by the fundraising page created for Bailey, a 23-year-old American who needed money to help pay for her abortion. The page raised more than $2,100, but also received many vicious comments and was eventually removed by the crowdfunding site GoFundMe. A woman should have the right to raise money for a legal operation from others who support her right to have one http://econ.st/1plbvez

Who torpedoed independence? The defeat of nationalism in Scotland can be put down to any number of interventions. But few are likely to credit George Osborne, the Conservative chancellor of the exchequer. Yet Mr Osborne greatly helped the unionist cause - without meaning to http://econ.st/1uMyLYw

"The final lie" was what some Argentines called the December 2013 inflation figures published by their country's statistics agency (INDEC). After the IMF threatened to censure the country for tampering with inflation data, in January INDEC rolled out a new consumer price index (CPINu). At last, the numbers would be more accurate. Or so people thought http://econ.st/1wFlq7B
Should Scotland be an independent country? We are interested in your view. Vote in our poll below and read more on this topic via http://econ.st/1qNHXMZ
Scots are voting on the question "Should Scotland be an independent country?". The Economist explains how the wording of the Scottish referendum could affect the outcome http://econ.st/1tmQINN

This week's cover preview:
Xi who must be obeyed
How one man now rules China
September 20th – 26th 2014
Read via: http://econ.st/1stU0ux

In the age of satellite television and the internet, supporting religious causes can be a political minefield. An increasingly vocal body of British legislators say they have a better idea: instead of rooting for particular religions, they want to campaign for liberty of conscience in general, stressing the need protect all belief systems, including atheism http://econ.st/1teEZRv

If Scotland becomes independent and adopts sterling as its currency, do not assume the arrangement will last long. Sooner or later, the same independent impulses that drove the political split will probably be felt in the monetary arena as well http://econ.st/1sse8gu

Iran is not the first topic that springs to mind in relation to Jon Stewart, an American television host and satirist. But in "Rosewater", his film debut that is due to be released in America in November, Mr Stewart tackles a subject few would expect to laugh about - the jailing and torture of a journalist in Tehran http://econ.st/1y7lcYp

Manuel Valls, the reformist French prime minister, faces a trying parliamentary vote of confidence in his Socialist government today, as he tries to face down backbench rebels unhappy with the direction of economic policy. People did not know they needed the Post-it note when it was first invented, but it is now ubiquitous. The young Kim Jong Un has quickly signalled change from his father's paranoid rule over North Korea, and with unexpected verve. Lost in the conversation about American economic recovery are the conditions that made a strong rebound possible in the past. Technology has given the fake ID business a boost. With today's software and printers, good fakes are easier to make. Kings make war, but wars also make kings. One of the oddest things about Homo sapiens is that he is alone. But that was not true in the past. As recently as 40,000 years ago there were three other species of human on Earth: Neanderthals, the "hobbits" of Flores, and a recently discovered group called the Denisovans. A crisis in higher education has been brewing for years in America. Universities have been spending like students in a bar who think a Rockefeller will pick up the tab. If Dr Bonn is right, sand engineers could beat the current record for the tallest sandcastle http://econ.st/Qh5Jci

For the first time since 1998 more money leaves China than enters it. Mainland China can now boast over 1m wealthy citizens each with over £1m.  But they seem to be having trouble keeping them. Japan's debt bubble had caused a "lost decade", from 1991 to 2001. Analysts commonly drew three lessons. Many words, such as terms for popular food products (coffee, for example) or scientific jargon, are similar or identical in otherwise unrelated languages. Perhaps we don't always need translations http://econ.st/MZV0bb

After the collapse of communism, Romania faced an education crisis that it has not tackled yet. Since 1989, the minister of education was changed 19 times. One of the reasons for their failure is that education in Romania was never properly financed http://econ.st/Ngq56Q

The right to bear arms faces a paradox. Can it, as enshrined in the constitution, derive from God, or from the very nature of being human? Or is this a special sort of right, one that can be created by the people via government if they so choose? Such are the idle thoughts that occur in the aftermath of America's latest episode of horrifying, meaningless mass slaughter http://econ.st/O86XcJ

Two new books offer well-argued versions of the idea that the West's true financial malaise is not mechanical but moral: a love of money, markets and material things. Anyone who sets store by capitalism and markets will find both books uncomfortable reading. They should be read all the same. http://econ.st/O5wxz0

Economists have regularly failed to predict recessions and were completely caught out by the recent financial crisis, as the Queen famously noticed. The shortfalls of the profession are old news http://econ.st/O5vaAp

Federal income taxes account for just 27% of total government revenue collected in America, and the middle class may not pay much federal income tax. But they sure pay the payroll tax for Social Security, which the rich can mostly skip out on since it only applies to the first $110,000 of wage income http://econ.st/O5E3Gq

Instagram takes a perfect, crisp image from a smartphone and runs it through filters that crop it into a square and artificially wilt the photo to look as if it were taken with a 1970s snapshot camera. The process is entirely digital. A new app, called InstaCRT, goes a step further, marrying an app and truly analog technology http://econ.st/O23I2B

The federal government has no law forbidding "attractiveness discrimination". Only a few places do: Washington, DC, and Santa Cruz and San Francisco in California. Instead, lawsuits proceed on the fact that it is usually illegal to discriminate on the basis of sex, race, religion, disability or national origin. So when can an employer prefer the attractive over the homely? http://econ.st/O219h7
This week's KAL's cartoon http://econ.st/O3XUcA

Daily Chart: The dream decade for emerging markets may be over. China is struggling to grow as fast as 8% (in 2003 it experienced double digit growth) and India, a country that once aspired to double-digit growth, can now only dream of ridding itself of double-digit inflation. http://econ.st/O3cBwz

Silvio Berlusconi will probably run for prime minister for a seventh time. His plan, said aides, is to relaunch his party, the Freedom People, on the basis of the free-market principles he espoused when he first entered office in 1994, but which he signally failed to apply in the nine subsequent years when he governed Italy http://econ.st/O0uQTB

Qatar Airways remains the best airline in the world, according to Skytrax, a company specialising in airline and airport research which publishes annual rankings. Its top ten is dominated, as ever, by eastern carriers, with three from the Middle East, six from Asia and one from Turkey http://econ.st/NVu46w

This week's cover preview:
Syria
Towards the endgame
July 21st – 27th 2012

A charming video has been bouncing around the internet. In it, two non-Danes living in Copenhagen bang together some electronics to create talking street signs, telling confused foreigners how to pronounce things like Kvæsthusgade and Rådhusstræde. If you don't know Danish, your best guess will probably not even be close http://econ.st/NPHDo0
link_name: The very rough guide to Danish

status_message: New York City has a reputation as a rough place; a town where you never know who is packing a pistol. A heat map by John Keefe at WNYC, the city's big public radio station, does a great job of showing where people are stopped and frisked the most, as well as where weapons are most commonly found http://econ.st/NVtfhJ

Daily Chart: Countries' rates of physical activity. Malta is the most slothful nation, with 72% of adults getting too little exercise. In America, six in ten are sufficiently active, compared with less than four in ten Britons http://econ.st/NWhV53

The fact that both American political parties are happy to portray China as the bogeyman of globalisation creates an impression of uniform hostility. That, in turn, undermines America's message that China is unduly paranoid and defensive http://econ.st/NL5wwK

The fact that Britain effectively set interest rates for the world was a great source of prestige and soft power. LIBOR should not have been so carelessly handled that it may now be destroyed for no other reason than that people have lost faith in Britain's ability to play by and police the rules http://econ.st/NVuYUi

It is estimated that 16m straight women are married to gay men in China. Zhang Beichuan, a scholar, estimates that more than 70% of gay men marry straight women. Using census data from 2011, Mr Zhang estimates that somewhere between 2-5% of Chinese men over the age of 15 are gay, or between 11m and 29m http://econ.st/Q1u0br

"Quantitative easing" (QE), the creation of money to buy assets, has proved to be the most popular weapon of this financial crisis. Speculation is growing that the Federal Reserve may launch another round of QE, perhaps as soon as next month. With QE increasingly pivotal to monetary policy, how much bang for the buck does it deliver? http://econ.st/P9TjXq
We have a special, limited time offer for new subscribers:  Get the first 12 weeks of The Economist for only $1.  Learn more about it at: http://bit.ly/OA7W1j

A 24-year-old engineer's recent innovation, dubbed "Le Chal" ("take me along" in Hindi) pairs a smartphone app with a small actuator sewn inside the sole of one shoe via Bluetooth. The user tells the phone his desired destination, which is translated into electronic commands using voice-recognition software http://econ.st/P7MSEi

There has been a fundamental shift in the nature of American growth over the past generation: a substantial, ongoing concentration in its gains the result of which is soaring inequality. Rising inequality is by no means confined to the American economy, though the dispersion of the American income distribution is among the most dramatic in the rich world http://econ.st/Mu87uK

Could a strongman's daughter be South Korea's first female leader? According to opinion polls, there is a good chance that Park Geun-hye could become the first female president of a country where only half of women work and a tenth of politicians are female http://econ.st/P6OgHb

What would it be like to live in an America where doctors routinely assisted terminally ill patients who wanted to commit suicide? Well, look around. That's what it would be like. Every day, doctors in America assist terminally ill patients who want to commit suicide. In all but three states, this is illegal, so it's impossible to know precisely how often it happens, because doctors can't talk about it openly http://econ.st/MrIoDa

In a paper that has gone viral in the past few days, entitled "Trajectory of a falling Batman", researchers try and calculate whether Batman's cape is aerodynamically suited for leaping off tall buildings. They consider the surface area of the wings at full stretch, the caped crusader's presumed body weight and height http://econ.st/P4WhfB
This week's KAL's cartoon http://econ.st/P4ZP1w

American-style capitalism has not had an easy time of the fnancial crisis. Crashing financial markets, bank bail-outs and high unemployment have all added to a growing sense of unease about a system that is based on private ownership of resources. Two new books attempt to restore the faith http://econ.st/LltxyZ
link_name: For those who have lost faith

status_message: Daily Chart: Over the past decade, thanks largely to the rush for resources, Inner Mongolia has recorded the fastest GDP growth of any Chinese province. But all of this is bringing few obvious benefits to Mongols, who find it hard to get jobs in the prospering cities http://econ.st/P4CixH

This week's cover preview:
Comeback kid
Rebuilding America's economy 
July 14th - 20th 2012

A new index on food security released this week by the Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) uncovers a few fascinating findings. The most interesting is that if women had access to the same productive resources as men—better seeds, fertilisers and fungicides—they could increase their yield by 20% to 30% http://econ.st/P17Gx5
link_name: Eat better? Let women do the work...

status_message: Daily chart: Which countries think that the rich deserve their fortune? Some 39% of adults think that the rich in their country deserve their wealth according to GlobeScan, a market-research company which polled 12,000 people in 23 countries http://econ.st/MiIa15

The giant American conglomerate General Electric (GE) holds more assets abroad than any other non-financial firm in the world—over $500 billion worth. Its foreign assets make up over 70% of its total. Of the 100 companies with the most foreign assets, 17 hold over 90% of their assets abroad http://econ.st/O1LiPd

Should the euro-zone's debt be mutualised? Advocates say mutualisation would both help reduce weak countries' unsustainable borrowing costs and create a safe asset that banks could hold. Critics say joint bonds are a recipe for the profligate to spend wildly on the credit of others. Join our latest online debate and share your views via our website at: http://econ.st/Mi9MUi

Teams at Harvard and the University of Hong Kong have been using new software that allows them to watch the censoring of posts on Chinese social-media sites more closely than before. According to one report, a team of researchers at Harvard found that 13% of all social-media posts in China were censored http://econ.st/O1KeuO

Daily chart: Which companies are the most—and least—open in their dealings? Companies registered in Europe and America tend to score higher along with those in the oil and finance sectors. Technology companies and firms from Japan less so. http://econ.st/LF4ats

Shenzhen, China's original Special Economic Zone (SEZ) is an empty 15-square-kilometre area earmarked for experimentation by China's cabinet. It will charge only 15% corporate-profit tax and levy no income taxes on the finance professionals, lawyers, accountants and creative people it hopes to eventually attract http://econ.st/NTHek4

Over the past week damning evidence has emerged that employees at Barclays and at several other unnamed banks tried to rig LIBOR time and again over a period of at least five years. And worse is likely to emerge. The scandal is about to go global http://econ.st/PCJsu9

On July 4th physicists working in Geneva at CERN, the world's biggest particle-physics laboratory, announced that they had found the Higgs boson. Its significance is massive. Literally. Without the Higgs there would be no mass. And without mass, there would be no stars, no planets and no atoms. And certainly no human beings http://econ.st/PviDYQ

Mixed marriages are inching up almost everywhere. In 25 of the 30 countries, there were more mixed marriages in 2008-10 than there had been in 2005-07. That might suggest that at the intimate level of family formation, "ever closer union" is becoming more of reality in Europe http://econ.st/NNjXQP

No country has gone as far as Turkey in trying to topple Syria's Bashar Assad. It has opened its doors to over 35,000 Syrian refugees, spearheaded the establishment of the opposition Syrian National Council. Yet Turkey's Syrian policy is failing to win public support http://econ.st/PrdDVi

It is 50 years since James Bond, another British icon, first appeared on screen. Age has not wearied the dashing spy, though his hair colour, accent and taste in women, cocktails and tailoring has changed. The Bond films are the longest-running and (adjusting for inflation) most lucrative franchise in cinema http://econ.st/NNhOEJ

Americans are much more willing to move around within their great continental expanse than residents of other countries are to migrate. Migration across state lines is far more common than is movement across Australian territories, Canadian provinces, or regions within the typical euro-area economy—and vastly more so than across national borderns within the EU http://econ.st/NElf0k

Our debate on cybersecurity has reached its conclusion. The motion: 'a hyperconnected world is more rather than less secure', is carried with 56% of the vote. To comment on the closing stages visit our website http://econ.st/NHzvpd or our new Facebook debates page http://econ.st/PiThNY

Germany's biggest carmaker is leaving rivals in the dust. Volkswagen boss Ferdinand Piëch's plan was for VW to become the world's biggest carmaker by volume by 2018. Last year, however, as Toyota struggled with the aftermath of Japan's tsunami and GM floundered in Europe, VW reached its goal seven years early http://econ.st/Pf5Bic

The average bear, it seems, is getting ever smarter. First, it turned out that at least one can use a comb. Now it appears that some can count, too.  But it is not entirely surprising that bears should possess a high degree of intelligence http://econ.st/NDQFnH
Daily chart: A closer look at LIBOR (the London inter-bank offered rate) submissions in 2008.  After Lehman Brothers collapsed, Barclays' numbers were among the highest. http://econ.st/PemedJ

This week's cover previews:
Worldwide ex UK: A giant leap for science. Finding the Higgs Boson
UK only: Banksters. Britain's price-fixing scandal and its global impact
July 7th - 13th 2012

At the beginning of the economic crisis, world leaders were determined not to repeat the mistakes of the 1930s, when protectionism led to economic disaster; and their apparent success in ensuring that global markets stayed open has been a rare glimmer of light in the economic gloom. But the world should heed warnings that barriers to trade are creeping back up http://econ.st/NllhfK

Daily chart: On July 4th researchers at CERN, Europe's main particle-physics lab, confirmed their discovery of something that looks very much like the Higgs boson. The world's most sought-after particle is the missing piece of the Standard Model, the best theory available for how the universe works in all its aspects bar gravity http://econ.st/NywtU9

In an interview with El Pais last week, Romanian Prime Minister Victor Ponta promised to resign if proven that his PhD about the International Criminal Court was an act of plagiarism. He made those statements before the ethics committee in charge gave its ruling, with its chairman saying it was plagiarised "copy-paste style" http://econ.st/NwUDhL
link_name: My name is Paste. Copy Paste.

status_message: Hong Kong is the "best city" in the world, according to the winning entry in a competition devised by the Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) and BuzzData, a data-sharing company. Competitors were asked to combine data from the EIU's liveability ranking with data from other sources to create a new ranking http://econ.st/P4CBcQ

Google advances its plan to bring smart glasses to the masses, which reflect a growing interest in wearable computing. Many experts think could be the next big thing in personal technology after smartphones and tablets http://econ.st/NlW4Q4

Four years ago, Spain's national football team were considered the great underachievers of the game. When the Spanish swept aside Italy by four goals to nil on July 1st, the list of overachievement spilled off the bottom of the page.

No other country has won two European titles in a row, let alone carry off a World Cup in between, as Spain did in 2010. And no one else has scored four goals in a European final.  http://econ.st/M04ZaP

Gauging an economy by its GDP is like judging a company by its quarterly profits, without ever peeking at its balance-sheet. Happily, the United Nations this month published balance-sheets for 20 nations which included three kinds of asset: "manufactured", or physical, capital; human capital; and natural capital http://econ.st/NlYXAv

Tales abound of dogs celebrating joy in a household or commiserating when tragedy strikes. This may not seem surprising after 15,000 years of co-evolution. But what hard evidence is there of dogs' empathy with humans? A new experiment suggests that behind all the waggy tails there really is something deeper going on http://econ.st/OSHVji

Russians have a deep suspicion of rich and successful people—a suspicion nurtured by communism and reinforced by the oligarchs of the 1990s, who owed their wealth to political connections and acted like Soviet caricatures of capitalist robber barons. Russia's version of the World Economic Forum highlights in particular its ambivalence about capitalism http://econ.st/OQneEA

One study in 2010 by researchers at Indiana University analyzed millions of tweets to predict the movement of the stock market three days later with an 87% accuracy. Such success has unleashed a new fashion for Wall Street quants to plug so-called "sentiment analysis" of social media into their massive models http://econ.st/NjDeZT

London's position at the top of the world is more precarious than it feels. The city's success over the past quarter-century has been the consequence of historical accident and good policy. Now history is moving on, and the policymakers are messing up. They could tip the city into a decline without even noticing it, for the ecosystem of a great city is a complex and fragile thing http://econ.st/OJCuEA

The internet, by allowing anonymous browsing and rapid price-comparing, was supposed to mean low, and equal, prices for all. Now, however, online retailers are being offered software that helps them detect shoppers who can afford to pay more or are in a hurry to buy, so as to present pricier options to them or simply charge more for the same stuff http://econ.st/LlV7bU

Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms agents found that an Arizona man who purchased 476 firearms for $300,000 over six months was on food stamps. This would seem to suggest that he was a straw-purchaser of firearms—someone used by criminals to buy their guns for them. But the assistant US attorney in Phoenix warned agents about taking action against him http://econ.st/LlY5NF

Just as the Italians were playing their last minutes of football on Thursday night, news emerged of the far more dangerous game being played by Mario Monti's team at the EU summit. The Italian delegation, with support from the Spanish, declared it would block all agreement until they got a deal on a mechanism to bring down their high borrowing costs http://econ.st/LlzqZD
link_name: Victory in football, self-defeat in summit?

status_message: India's rupee has lost a fifth of its value against the dollar in the past year, reflecting global woes but also a slowdown in India and a drying up of capital inflows. But IKEA, a Swedish furniture chain, boosted morale by saying it would invest up to €1.5 billion ($1.9 billion) in the country—although on closer inspection that sum was spread over many years. Coca-Cola followed suit with the announcement of an additional $3 billion in investment http://econ.st/OJn4Ac

Feminism never arrived into China with a thunderous crack, but elements have crept in over the past 40 years. Mao Zedong famously said women "hold up half the sky", and during the Cultural Revolution they worked alongside men. But in the 1990s feminism was still largely an academic pursuit. Lately, however, small-scale feminist protests have been popping up  http://econ.st/LlwNXR

Chinese astronaut Liu Yang stands as an example of one of the most significant trends in China today: the emergence of a new generation of women, educated, ambitious and successful, who are playing pivotal roles in the country's economic and social development http://econ.st/OEJBOK

If bank executives cannot be held responsible for all the shenanigans that go on underneath them, nor can they be responsible for all the profits that result. A lot goes on at a bank that is entirely out of the CEO's control http://econ.st/Ljtnop

Our debate on cybersecurity has reached the rebuttal phase. So far 60% agree that a hyperconnected world is a more secure one. Join our speakers arguing for and against the motion along with The Economist's technology editor, presiding as moderator via our website: http://econ.st/LVu48i or via our new debate hall on Facebook: http://on.fb.me/L89mWg

Reporters from the Wall Street Journal have found several families that have gone to unusual lengths to teach their children Mandarin. One Californian lawyer took a year's leave of absence from work and moved the clan to Chengdu, for the sole purpose of immersion in the language. Another family moved to Singapore in 2007, again only so the kids could grow up speaking Mandarin http://econ.st/LiXuMw

As so often in law, the court's ruling on America's 2010 health-care reform law turned on many points of language. It's important, then, that Chief Justice John Roberts argued that there was never any "mandate" to buy insurance: the word does not appear in the law. Rather, those who don't carry insurance must pay a "penalty", which the law also called a "shared responsibility payment" http://econ.st/Lj459W
link_name: When is a mandate not a mandate and a penalty not a penalty?

status_message: The Supreme Court has sided with Barack Obama on his health reform, by five votes to four. John Roberts, the chief justice, joined the court's four liberals in upholding the Democrats' biggest legislative feat in decades. The law requires Americans to buy insurance or pay a penalty—the so-called "individual mandate". The decision is a huge relief for the president and his allies http://econ.st/ODkjR3

This week's cover preview:
On a high
London's precarious brilliance
June 30th-July 6th 2012

Daily chart: Countries can set restrictive or permissive policies on immigration, but the main driver of how many people come is the availability of jobs. So which countries have naturalised the most immigrants over the past decade? http://econ.st/OzaCTw

It doesn't quite make sense that some people think that their personal comma preference is linguistic law. There are those who think the "Oxford comma" is the last barricade protecting civilisation from the barbarians, and those who are equally convinced of the opposite.  But there are almost as many comma conventions that change from text to text, writer to writer and age to age http://econ.st/Lfuq8E

The frequency with which the world goes to hell in September seems hardly random. No matter the explanation, this gives more reason, as if you needed more, to sweat as the fall approaches. Just to elevate the anxiety further: another calendar pattern is the tendency for crises to happen in election years; think Mexico, 1982 and 1994, Korea, 1998, America, 2008, Greece, 2009 http://econ.st/LcE1NI
link_name: The cruelest month of the cruelest year

status_message: Daily chart: Cannabis continues to be the world's illicit drug of choice. So which countries have the highest rates of cannabis use? http://econ.st/OsGCZq

Claudia Castillo, a 30-year-old Colombian who was living in Barcelona, needed a new trachea. Her doctors decided to try something new-they'd give her a transplant, but they'd dip the organ in a bath of her own stem cells. That way, it would grow her own cells on it and her immune system would be less likely to reject the trachea as a foreign object. The procedure was the first of its kind http://econ.st/LcEEqC
link_name: Is that a trachea in your pocket, sir?

status_message: The Arab world's most conservative monarchy must change fast or die. Despite the colossal wealth of the ruling class in Saudi Arabia, the number of poor is surprisingly large. A third of Saudi young people are jobless. The 140,000 or so Saudis studying abroad will want a say when they return http://econ.st/OfEV1v
link_name: Time for the old men to give way

status_message: Investors beware: François Hollande is set to take France in the wrong direction even faster than you feared. He will start by cutting the retirement age for some workers to 60, putting the top marginal income-tax rate up to 75%, raising taxes on wealth, inheritance and dividends, increasing the minimum wage and making it much harder for employers to fire workers http://econ.st/L7N16N

If you're so smart, why aren't you rich? That question exasperates most economists, who model markets better than they play them. One possible exception is John Maynard Keynes, who has always had a reputation as a star-performing investor. A fascinating new paper takes a closer look at his money-making record http://econ.st/KZaeYG

Translating swear words is hard. Often there is a literal equivalent. But some words are strictly taboo in one language, while the exact same word in another language might be pretty mild. It works the other way round, too http://econ.st/KVjahA

This week's cover preview
Egypt in peril
June 22nd - 29th 2012

Of the scores of middle-income countries in 1960, only 13 passed that threshold to become high-income economies by 2008. One of those elect 13 was Greece. Its per capita income was only 28% of America's in 1960. That is very roughly where China stands today http://econ.st/NLTA4c

The greater mystery to some is not how many Greek deposits have gone, but how many remain. When banks need to be recapitalised and when the guarantee of the Greek government carries little weight, the rational thing to do is to take money out of the bank, to either send it abroad or put it under the mattress. Why aren't more Greeks doing it? http://econ.st/KEQPvS

American rapper and hip-hop producer Lil Jon has something to teach us about grammaticalisation, which is the process by which an ordinary non-grammatical word begins to become a grammatical one bleached of its original meaning http://econ.st/KEOzF6

Daily chart: The perception in some countries that America is no longer the world's pre-eminant economy is somewhat premature. As today's chart shows, such perceptions vary enormously across the world according to a new poll carried out in 21 countries by the Pew Research Centre http://econ.st/Nm8Ogf

Has the US government under Mr Obama worked well enough to warrant his re-election? The Economist's website is running an online debate with the motion: 'This house believes that Barack Obama deserves to be re-elected' and we are interested to hear your views. Vote below or to join the discussion visit our debate hall via our website: www.economist.com/debate

This week's cover preview:
The vanishing north
What the melting Arctic means for trade, energy and the environment
June 16th-22nd 2012

In Ray Bradbury's stories, which are ubiquitous in high-school and university curriculums, he predicted things like ear buds, ATMs and flatscreen TVs. Bradbury himself never went to college, and said he got all the education he needed from libraries http://econ.st/MMl5u1

This week's cover preview
The World Economy
June 9th-15th 2012

Millions around the world would have their lives improved by a pair of glasses, but cannot afford one. How to help such people is a problem with which Joshua Silver has been grappling for many years. His answer is cheap, self-adjusting glasses designed so that users can alter the power of the lenses in order to correct their own eyesight http://econ.st/MxqtkB

Daily chart: In which languages are internet passwords easiest to crack? Cambridge University computer scientist Joseph Bonneau has recently published an analysis of the passwords chosen by almost 70m (anonymised) Yahoo! users http://econ.st/MFhOg6

It is illegal for an employer to pay a woman less than a man for the same work just as it is illegal for a shop owner to charge a Jew more than a Christian for the same loaf of bread. But an argument of Rand Paul's implies that it should be okay http://econ.st/KhNL8U
link_name: Protecting individual rights is not Stalinist

The rather dangerous Monsieur Hollande

Daily chart: Who has the most plastic surgery? Having cosmetic surgery to enhance what nature gave you (or to keep her at bay) is increasingly common. In 2010 over 3.3m procedures were done in America, more than anywhere else. But when population is accounted for, South Korea tops the list http://econ.st/JzQ6wT

China's military rise

French presidential hopeful François Hollande is not a charismatic figure. In his campaign poster, pinned all over the walls at a recent event in Côte d'Azur, he looks like a history schoolteacher or a provincial bank manager. But on the ground, Mr Hollande does stir some pretty starstruck behaviour http://econ.st/H43NDP

This week's cover preview:

Continuing our week long discussion about the use of drone strikes, here are a couple more points for and against, taken from the Economist poster campaign running in London:

FOR drone strikes: Armed drones do not undermine the rules of war and remain conventional weapons, with humans subject to the conventional tests that their action be discriminate and proportionate.

AGAINST drone strikes: Drones are an invasion of privacy as they enable people's activities to be monitored continuously when they are outdoors, even when they are on their own private property.

Where do you stand? To see more about the poster campaign and to share additional comments via Twitter view our discussion page at: http://econ.st/AyXQST
link_name: Where do you stand on the use of drone strikes?

Is the use of drone strikes justified? Picking up additional points from the Economist poster campaign running in London, we are asking readers: where do you stand on the use of drone strikes?

FOR: It was America's use of SEALs and drones in Pakistan which killed Osama bin Laden and decimated al-Qaeda.

AGAINST: Drones may be accurate, but they still kill lots of unintended victims. A drone strike on insurgents in Pakistan in March 2011 may have killed more than 40 people, many of them civilians.

Where Do You Stand? To see more about the poster campaign and to share additional comments via Twitter view our discussion page at: http://econ.st/AyXQST
link_name: Where do you stand on the use of drone strikes?

status_message:
Continuing our discussion asking if the use of drone strikes can be justified, here are another set of points for and against taken from the current Economist poster campaign in London:

FOR: The American army has experimented with turning drones into miniature bombers; such bombs would be enough to destroy a small vehicle or take out the occupants of a particular room with high precision and little collateral damage.

AGAINST: Rich-country governments can use drones to get rid of their enemies without any risk to themselves. That is immoral, and likely to undermine self-restraint.

Where Do You Stand? To see more about the poster campaign and to share additional comments via Twitter view our discussion page at: http://econ.st/AyXQST
link_name: Where do you stand on the use of drone strikes?

This week we are picking up on a second discussion raised in the current Economist poster campaign on the London Underground: are drone strikes justifiable? Here's a couple of points for and against:

FOR drone strikes: Drones are so accurate that individual terrorist suspects or insurgents can be targeted with little risk to civilians.

AGAINST drone strikes: Drones are used to assassinate people, such as Anwar al-Awlaki, an American-born cleric killed in Yemen. That's not war, that's extra-judicial execution.

Where Do You Stand? To view the Economist poster and to view comments via Twitter go to: http://econ.st/AyXQST
link_name: Where do you stand on the use of drone strikes?

status_message:
Our discussion on social media censorship is coming to an end. Thank you to everyone who has shared their view on the topic this week. To wrap up here are a couple of additional points for and against social media censorship:

FOR censorship: False rumours can spread like wildfire and sow panic. Tweets about gunmen attacking schools in Mexico allegedly led to 26 car crashes.

AGAINST censorship: Rescue services increasingly rely on social networks for real-time information during emergencies, such as the Japan tsunami in 2011. Any restrictions could cost lives.

To see more about the poster campaign and to continue the conversation, visit our discussion page at: http://econ.st/wFLbXj #wdys
link_name: Where do you stand on social media censorship?

status_message:
This week's cover previews are now available to view our photo album. We have two covers this week:

North America: Over-regulated America

Should social media be censored? Picking up on additional points raised in the new Economist poster campaign running in London we are asking readers: Where Do You Stand on social media censorship? Here are some more thoughts:

AGAINST censorship: Social media have created an upheaval in the way we communicate, but so did the telephone in its day, and email too. The idea of censorship is just a knee-jerk reaction to sudden change.

FOR censorship: Social media don't just let two people communicate; they make everyone a potential broadcaster, without any of the usual codes of ethics or professional standards. That's too much power in people's hands.

To see more about the poster campaign and to share additional comments via Twitter view our discussion page at: http://econ.st/wFLbXj #wdys
link_name: Where do you stand on social media censorship?

status_message:
Should social media be censored? Continuing our discussion based on points raised in the new Economist poster campaign running on the London underground here are some additional points for and against social media censorship. Where Do You Stand?

FOR: Parents can choose to block adult websites on a child's computer, but they can't currently block pornography on a social network.

AGAINST: Nobody supports blanket censorship for books, films or the press. Social media are no different in principle from other media.

To see more about the poster campaign and to share additional comments via Twitter view our discussion page at: http://econ.st/wFLbXj #wdys
link_name: Where do you stand on social media censorship?

status_message:
Should social media be censored? Picking up on the points raised in the new Economist poster campaign running in London we are asking readers: Where Do You Stand on social media censorship? Here's a case for and against taken from the poster ads:

AGAINST: Social media allow people who might never otherwise meet to connect with each other. That gives them unparalleled opportunities to build both personal and professional contacts, which censorship would limit. 

FOR: Social media allow private companies to amass tremendous amounts of information on people with no regulation or oversight. There need to be better safeguards for privacy, including limiting the kinds of information people can share.

To see more about the poster campaign and to share additional comments via Twitter view our discussion page at: http://econ.st/wFLbXj #wdys
link_name: Where do you stand on social media censorship?

In America women last year made up less than 18% of senior managers and not even 8% of the highest earners. Among the Fortune 500 companies only about 15% of the most senior managers and only 3% of the CEOs were women. There are not nearly enough skirts in the boardroom. Join the author of our special report on women and work for a live discussion via our website from 11am ET / 4pm GMT. To ask a question comment below, or tweet with #askeconomist  http://econ.st/tYC4Zk

Women have made progress in the workplace but still get lower pay and fewer top jobs than men. Ask the author of our special report on the subject why in our live discussion today at 4pm GMT/ 11am ET. To pose a question comment below or use #askeconomist on twitter http://econ.st/vZNMkI

Changes in technology mean that choosing a big-screen television has become more complicated than ever. Should you pay extra for 1080p resolution, LED backlighting or 3D? We crunch the numbers http://econ.st/uIPsdw

Men are still more likely than women to be in paid work, but the most vexing gap between the sexes is the continued disparity in earnings according to our recent special report labelled 'Women and work'.  In America the gap between wages has halved since 1970, from 40% to 20%; across the OECD the gap averages around 18%. Join the author of the special report, Barbara Beck, for a live discussion on the subject from 11am EDT, Tuesday December 6th. You can pose questions to Ms Beck by commenting below or using #askeconomist on twitter. For more details and to follow the live discussion to go: http://econ.st/w3Kfxk

Shifting sands. A glimpse of outdoor promotion activity for The Economist in the Middle East, Spring 2011

Keeping track of shifting sands
For the latest outdoor activity in the Middle East, we needed an innovative way to promote The Economist, with an idea that had both local insight and was relevant to the region. 
To achieve this, we placed a custom-made billboard in the sand dunes on a busy highway between Dubai and Oman. The desert then played its part in bringing the idea to life. As the weeks went by, the sand dunes shifted and our message was delivered to thousands of motorists and even a few curious camels.
link_name: Shifting sands. Outdoor promotion activity for The Economist

Enjoy a fresh and hilarious look at politics when the weekly magazine The Economist partners with renowned comedy theatre troupe The Second City for a one-of-a-kind evening of engaging improv and hands-on cartooning featuring The Economist's political cartoonist Kevin 'Kal' Kallaugher. Politics will never look the same again.

Find out more at www.artofsatire.economist.com

Explore the brilliance of The Economist's cartoonist, kevin 'Kal' Kallaugher as he muses on thirty years in the business.  Learn about The Economist's live variety show collaboration with the crafty political satirists from The Second City.  Taste the best of the pithy, quotable bile from around the US campaign trail in The Economist's 'Primary Colour' column.  And, enjoy short comdey clips from The Second City.

status_message: Kevin Kallaugher, better known to readers as KAL, joined The Economist in April 1978. In celebration of three decades of mockery, Economist.com has reproduced some of his favourite cartoons. KAL discusses these drawings and his career at The Economist in this video, the first in a series

status_message: TV commercial for The Economist in the UK from 1996. This eight-week campaign featured a businessman settling down to enjoy an international flight when he realises with terror that Mr. Kissinger will be his seatmate. The commercial plays on the businessman's fear of having to hold his own in conversation with such an intellect, and offers the Economist as a means for businessmen to be well informed. http://youtu.be/1vTMogcvVeM

"Let them wed" January 6th 1996

Archive: June 26th 1982 print edition

The heir to the British throne keeps doing things right. Eleven months ago, he married the best of all possible princesses. This week, she gave him the heir to the heirdom, and he carried the baby out of St Mary's hospital 37 hours after his wife had gone in. What Queen Victoria did for chloroform, the Princess of Wales has done for short stays in the maternity wards. 

The happiest stories are often the shortest ones. But this one will run on for years. The baby in question will probably still be head of state in the year 2050.
